description:
This place wouldn't have been on my immediate list to go to for brunch as there are endless options around that appear trendier, popular, stand out more, etc. so I was surprised at how good it all was!

You order at the counter first, then sit at your table and wait for them to bring the food to you - we were lucky to snag a couple limited outdoor seats and enjoy the perfect weather on Saturday afternoon while brunching. I had the eggs Benedict (which is something I usually avoid due to its absolute basic-ness) and maybe because I hadn't consumed this specific item in so long, it was amazing! The eggs were perfectly runny, the bread buttery, the sauce tasty... but I know for sure that those potatoes were possibly the best brunch potatoes I have ever had - so crispy on the outside! I liked that they even included the fruit bowl. Although I had to remind the waiter I ordered a drink, the latte was great. My friend's French toast was delicious also. Shoutout to this friend who lives nearby for taking me here.
author: Tasha V.

description:
I visited for a weekday working lunch and enjoyed my experience.

You order at the counter and can take a number to sit inside or at a few tables out on the sidewalk. I ordered the smoked salmon tartine, which came with a generous side salad. The tartine was flavorful, but I wish they added a little bit more salmon and sliced tomatoes. However, I still thought it was a good value at $10.

It was not too busy on a weekday so I didn't feel guilty about staying to work a little. The WiFi was speedy and easy to connect to. I also appreciated the water station. I would return for a working lunch.
author: Roya B.

description:
I cannot believe this cafe has an average of four stars. People who are writing "cute Parisian vibe" and similar twaddle have obviously never been to Paris. This is a totally unremarkable, sub-standard cafe with nothing going for it other than a good location in a heavily touristed area.

I went here a year ago for lunch, found it disappointing, and, just today, went to check whether anything had changed. Nope. Here's what I had:
- Croissant: at 3pm, this tasted stale and dry. There was a remnant of a buttery inside, but it's no prize winner. It was also unfortunately large and ill-shapen; a work of careless craftsmanship.
- Apple crumble: pure sugar, with an aged and cold interior. This one's been sitting here for a while. 
- Latte: absolute swill. My latte machine at work could deliver a better drink. It is a large, 16oz latte, but it's totally unpalatable all the same. As I write this review, related recent reviews show that a man named "Michal" has given Brioche five stars with the explanation that the "lattes are huge", which makes me wonder (a) what exactly the bar is for getting a five-star review in this dude's book and (b) if all you care about is quantity, then I've got some dishwater to sell to you.
author: John L.

description: Tucked away on the corner of Columbus and Pacific behind Reveille Coffee. This place is not as trendy as the coffee shop next door but it's a cute mom and pop cafe. I ordered a delicious croissant sandwich! It's filled with tomato, cheese and egg with sausage. You order at the counter and find a table to sit. There are a couple of tables in the cafe for seating.
author: Ayumi W.

description:
Omg the most delicious breakfast place in town! We passed by this little place and loved the vibe. 

Sugar brioche was phenomenol! Personally I'm not a fan of sweet breakfast but this was an exception. It's not overly sweet and the bread was soft

Also had the spinach and gruyere omelette with fresh fruit and homestyle potatoes. The potatoes were seasoned perfectly. The omelette was oozing with cheese and tasted great!

Definitely come out to this place if you're in the SF area!
author: Jannat C.

description:
Meh- wasn't my favorite brunch spot but maybe we ordered the wrong stuff.  Came here with my date for a super late brunch on a Sunday.

Venue / service: cute Parisian cafe vibe inside.  Small tables that are close to each other.  You place your order at the front and sit down with a number, after which they'll bring your food to you.  Staff were nice and seemed patient from the little interaction we had with them.

-- French Onion Soup (served gratinéed with croutons and Gruyere)($5.25) - unfortunately a massive miss, and we both agree on this.  Severely under-seasoned; both of us commented that it could have used a LOT of salt (and we usually don't make a comment like that).  Not a lot of cheese either- it literally was one slice of gruyere and you couldn't get a bite of cheese with every bite.

-- Spinach & Gruyere Omelet (sautéed organic baby spinach and onions with Gruyere cheese, served with oven roasted rosemary potatoes and fruit. Add bacon or chicken apple sausage +$3.75)($11.75) - again, slightly under-seasoned, probably could have used a different cheese.  At least they loaded it with a lot of spinach so you feel somewhat healthy for eating your veggies, though the overall effect was still heavy.  Potatoes were non-eventful, and the fruit was ok (the watermelon wasn't sweet at all).  Chicken sausage at least was moist and flavorful.

-- Chicken Pot Pie (forgot price) - probably the best dish we had that day.  The filling inside was slightly different (a bit redder color-wise) than your typical filling, but quite tasty!  Lot of chicken chunks and a decent amount of veggies.  Only wish there was a crust at the bottom of the pie.

All together, with a green tea, the price came out to less than $40.  Not sure if it was worth it more.  Maybe we didn't order the right stuff, but not sure I'll be back... I feel like I could get a better brunch somewhere else.
author: Audrey H.

description:
Found this place when I was looking for a cafe to study at. Place is at a great location overlooking Columbus ave with lots of natural light! There were a couple of outlets for charging. Environment was relatively quiet and got busy during lunch hours. 
The fresh orange juice was delicious and so was the granola bowl. I just wish it had more strawberries and less sunflower seeds. The yogurt was sweetened with honey which made it delicious. The serving size was a bit larger than your typical granola parfait and imo could be eaten as a meal.
author: Areeba Q.

description:
Meh.  Lovely view, mediocre food which I didn't eat but half of, and coffee.  Right next to the bus stop, so....

Service is quite slow.  I got my (microwaved) and enormous quiche before the coffee came, which I had to inquire after two times post order.  Salad is undressed.  Staff is sleep walking, both figuratively and just about literally--the lassitude is palpable. They would clearly rather be elsewhere.

Decorating is French and that's as far as it goes.  Not a frenchy in sight.

Can't recommend this place I'm afraid, other than it being attractive to walk past.
author: Mmmm H.

description:
We were debating where to go for brunch in the morning and didn't want to wait in line too long so we settled on trying Brioche after seeing the 4 star rating on Yelp. 

The way it works: Order at the register, grab a number and grab a table (open seating). We ordered the Avocado scramble, Vanilla brioche French toast, fresh squeezed OJ, and a side of bacon.

We grabbed the fresh squeezed OJ and a table outside since it was a nice sunny day. The OJ was delicious and refreshing, I would recommend trying it. 
About 10-15 minutes later our food arrived to our table. 

The Avocado scramble: Half a slice of avocado thinly sliced over a well cooked pile of eggs with 2 handfuls of oven roasted potatoes and a small cup of cut fruit. The size of the meal was standard for the price, the eggs were cooked well, but wish there had been more avocado.

Vanilla Brioche French toast - Sounds fancy and delicious but is small and disappointing for the price. 3 half slices of approximately regular sized bread, not fully battered with egg and sprinkled on top with powdered sugar and a few strawberries and raspberries. Comes with syrup. 
:( I was hoping for this dish to be the highlight of the meal, but I make better French toast at home (my French toast is nothing great). Not worth the $.

The side of bacon - Was completely burnt. When I say completely I mean completely. I tried to eat half of one piece but it was just not enjoyable/worth it to pay for burnt bacon so we asked if we could have a new plate instead. They immediately took back our plate and gave us a replacement plate 5 minutes later. The second plate was definitely way better! :) Someone from the staff came to check on us to make sure things were okay after the bacon fail, which was nice. 

Pros:
- No line
- Outside and inside seating available
- Good for reading a book or studying inside 
- Good customer service 

Things to note:
- Not good for groups, tables are very small
- Very noisy if you sit outside as the Muni stop is right where you are sitting/fire engines seem to use this road particularly 
- Chairs outside are folding chairs (no cushions) that you might use in your backyard if you have too many people over for a party 

Overall a casual cafe to grab a bite or drink to go, have coffee with a friend or study, but I wouldn't come back for brunch solely based on the quality of the food.
author: Saachi G.

description: Stopped in for an early sunday breakfast at 7am while waiting on the BART after a night shift. I got the french toast, a 3 layered mini chocolate cake, and house coffee. The desert was decadent and they had a great selection of them. My french toast was really good. It had a light hint of vanilla and enough strawberries, raspberries, and black berries for at least one in every bite. The coffee was meh tho. It was generic tasting and had been sitting in one of those self serve gas station dispensers.
author: Sean G.

description:
Found out about Brioche Bakery after visiting their tent at the Burlingame Farmer's Market one Sunday morning.

I had their lemon pound cake which was so moist and delicious, and their other pastries and breads looked so saliva-cious...I know that's not even a real word. But we were both DROOLING gazing at all of the items that were displayed at their tent. I asked the kind lady what bakery this was, and she said Brioche Bakery in SF. 

Took the boo here, and we came for a light breakfast/brunch. I'm usually pretty over the SF brunch scene because waiting for an hour or more is not on my to-do list early in the morning. But Brioche was not a "brunch spot" and instead, more of a bakery with breakfast items like french toast or croque monsier's to order. They have French items, but also quick baked goods like quiches at the ready...and lasagna too. We shared the french toast and spinach/tomato quiche. Both were delicious and warm, as we decided to sit inside and enjoy our morning meal. They have serve-yourself water and a variety of seating--they share indoor space with what looks like a winery that is closed in the morning. There are a few outdoor seating options for those with dogs or people wanting a smoke. 

Everything was delicious and the wait for food was maybe a solid 10-15 minutes. Not bad. Service is quick and efficient, and exactly what I want from a relaxed cafe morning breakfast experience.
author: Jodi H.

description:
Have visited this cafe many times for years and have never been disappointed. Quiet, charming, and plenty of natural sunlight. Owner and staff are always sweet. I most enjoy the sandwiches or quiches. 

And if you don't enjoy a certain restaurant, you don't have to be a douche and insult the business or other customers who enjoy it. (re: a review written 2 months ago by J.L.)
author: Mia L.

description: Reasonable pricing & food is good. Staff is very nice & service is quick. I sat outside since the weather was nice. There is a bus stop right in front of the store, if you want to eat outside just keep in mind that there will be some noise on occasion
author: Sinai P.

description:
On a rainy wet Sunday afternoon, and after lunch, I was looking for some sweet goodies with a good espresso that can bring me back to France or Italy! 
I read good reviews about this place, so I decided to give it a shot! And very glad I did!
I had a double espressos that was very good! Not too bitter, foamy with a strong coffee taste!
The opera cake was so tasty! Not too sweet as most of the American desserts and great texture that makes you feel the different layers composing the cake!
Cons: loud Latin music! I would prefer to have a calm/lounge music in the background.
author: Joe S.

description:
Brioche Bakery looks like a coffee shop , but they also offer more substantial brunch fare as well (egg benedict, omlettes, etc).  Simple and delicious food that's relatively inexpensive with quick and friendly service.  

I had the french breakfast (baguette with butter and jelly) and a fresh fruit cup with a cafe au lait.  Perfect for a Friday morning.
author: Holly P.

description:
While leaving China Town, and heading to Little Italy to grab a slice from Golden Boy Pizza (another AMAZING SF restaurant), I walked in here because I could see coffee and what looked like a cute cafe setting. I took one look at the menu, and decided to have lunch here instead. The salmon sandwich immediately stood out to me, so I quickly ordered one, which came with a side salad for just over $9.

There are two seating areas, one where you order food, and another to the left of it that serves as a wine bar in the evenings. I grabbed a seat in the wine bar, and was impressed by the natural lighting, and the simple fixtures and decor. The food arrived in just about 10 minutes, and the waiter was extremely sweet and offered me a refill on my water and brought out a hot sauce at my request.

The sandwich was out of this world! There was so much salmon on that sandwich that I felt like I should have paid twice as much, just for the salmon. The bread was wheat, and had a tasty lemon infused aioli applied to it, with the huge slices of salmon, lots of capers, and an additional 2-3 lemon slices. Every bite was just as flavorful and filling as the previous one. The salad was mixed greens, and had a vinegar based dressing, that had fruity hints. 

I could not believe I was able to score such quality food, both portion and taste wise for under $10. Next time, I am in the area, I am stopping in and trying another tasty dish.
author: Ruben M.

description:
We were attracted to this place as people were drinking their coffees from cups and saucers rather than cardboard takeaways 
It was an excellent choice. Cappuccinos were good, croissants were crispy and the price was right.
author: Sue L.

description:
Who knew that there would be such a cute little café on my way to work! This place is awesome.

I was craving a hearty breakfast so I called in an order to-go. When I went to pick up, the interior of the cafe was super cute and clean. There are tons of beautiful pastries in the display windows, all of them look absolutely delicious! The service was friendly and it was really easy for me to pick up my eggs benedict & mocha and head out the door.

The food was great! I loved the eggs benedict on the brioche toast (both eggs poached to perfection, thank God) and the mocha was one of the best I've ever had! I was really pleasantly surprised.

Brioche Cafe would be a great spot to grab a quick coffee/breakfast and read/do work. It's also an awesome place to get casual brunch with a friend (only small tables here so not good for groups) or people watch out the big windows overlooking Columbus Ave.
author: Desiree S.

description: Meh. Find somewhere else. The egg croissant sandwich was just okay. The coffee was weak. But it is cheap, so if that's all you care about...
author: Ashley A.

description: Great place to meet a friend for lunch. We felt that we were in Paris!
author: Emily M.

description: Their lattes are huge, cheese cakes are awesome, the place was clean and the people working there were super nice.
author: Michal G.

description:
Highly recommend this cafe for breakfast, brunch, and lunch. Best bread I've had in the city -- delish and interesting sandwiches. The ambience is very romantic in a French cafe sort of way with a quaint view of North Beach. 

Also, recommend just going in and picking up bread   if you happen to be in the neighborhood. They bake different nuts and dry fruit into them. My favorite is the walnut raisin.
author: Tanika T.

description: Incredible food with great service and reasonable prices, I can't recommend Brioche highly enough!
author: Darian N.

description:
I recently stumbled upon Brioche and was extremely happy about it! Their coffee here is SO CHEAP. Easily the cheapest coffee I've had in the city. Further, it's good coffee too!

Anytime I come here the workers are extremely friendly too. Have yet to try any food though, but their pastries always look delicious.
author: James D.

description:
Somehow we got in and out of here in about 20 minutes, including ordering and eating an eggs benedict! Which was incredible, btw. The hollandaise was super legit, Canadian bacon was a bit crispy on the edges, potatoes were delicious, AND the fruit bowl was actually good fruit! Lots of berries and only a couple pieces of cantaloupe. 

My husband had a yogurt parfait and loved it. He also had some sort of pastry that was like a cake/pie that was AMAZING. Don't remember the name. 

It's small and cute, a great option when the place next door is overly crowded!
author: Jessie B.

description:
Insect in my salad!

Just found a dead cricket in my salad. Not impressed at all and quite disgusted at the possibility of this happening. I'm all for extra protein, but not like this!
author: Emilie M.

description: I've passed this cafe twice a day, everyday for the past 3 months. I finally decided to go in and was glad I did! Great coffee and eggs Benedict with a lovely ambiance. Perfect neighborhood cafe. I'll definitely be back.
author: Jessica W.

description:
I discovered this spot quite randomly, because it's located right next to a tattoo shop that my friend gets work done from. We ended up making this tradition to come here for their Chicken Caesar Wraps every time he goes back to get a new tattoo, and man is that wrap delicious and addictive. While I can't really vouch for many other items that they have on the menu, I've been here enough times to know that the service is good and the wraps are just awesome. I'm big on the Caesar Salad one specifically because it's so light, uses a spinach tortilla and feels like it's the perfect balance of healthy and tasty. 

All in all, it's a great stop for a quick lunch, or just if you work in the area and want a pastry and coffee. I've seen a few people compare this location to La  Boulange, and I can see the resemblance, but they definitely have a unique identity of their own. Enjoy!
author: Alex B.

description: The bakery cafe is a cozy corner from which to watch the world pass by. It is more of a cafe, since the baking is done at their bakery. They have a wide assortment of desserts in addition to salads and sandwiches. I suggest the vegetarian lasagna, quiche or pear salad. Pastries are delicious, as are the beautiful breads. Customer service is warm and welcoming. Stop by when you're in the area!
author: Carol W.

description: Omg..I found this place only because it was a short walk from our hotel, and I am soooo glad I did! Honestly the quiche was the BEST I have ever had. I am a chef and a quiche lover and I'd love that recipe! The berry muffin my daughter got was heavenly too! I was shocked. The texture was light yet packed with flavor. It was divine. Everything looked pretty standard and yet the flavors and textures were outstanding. We all loved what we ordered. If we were staying longer we would have eaten there more often!
author: Candice F.

description:
Aces! Quality quality hot food, and quality baked goods. (I hate to admit that I had both for breakfast.) Restaurant also supplies newspapers for idling through while eating.

Slightly confusing in that they accept reservations on OpenTable, and showed as having no availability when I wanted to come in. But when I showed up, hoping for a walk-in, they only had 2 other people in the place.
author: Cathy B.

description: Delicious egg, chicken sausage, cheese, tomato breakfast croissant with side of lightly dressed greens. Cappuccino to die for! Will be back.
author: Jodi R.

description: Great brunch spot with a view of the old parts of the city. Outdoor setting was great because indoors was quite warm with fresh pastries. Tasty coffee and eggs Benedict.
author: Natalee L.

description: Great little spot strategically located on the edge of Chinatown and North Beach and Financial District.  Great food! Friendly people and service!  Highly recommend for a fun lunch!
author: Lynn A.

description:
We had the breakfast croissant and quiche. They were both delicious. Service was quick and coffee was very good as well. 

We were looking for a French bakery experience. Great little cafe!  Would definitely recommend.
author: Andrew W.

description:
While I'm waiting for my significant other (this trip was solely based on acquiring new platforms and dealings with investors) to finish with his new investor, I wandered the streets of San Francisco alone. I never mind him setting his meetings so far away. It only allows me to venture off and do a little sight seeing. 

I stumbled upon this quaint cafe as I'm crossing the street (I do not have a sense of direction, so I've been told, and have witnessed myself on this day) because I saw something shiny in the distance (anything shiny is a good sign, right) so I wanted to see it. But as I'm walking, I noticed that the shiny object was just a spoon that someone used to stir their coffee, duh. Oh! But it smelled so good and the scent of pastries lingering... Delicious! I had to order something just to save time. I had their caramel machiatto (the real deal... not the Starbucks kind) and what felt like eternity took them 3 minutes including the beautiful latte art. I also ordered a cheese brioche which was absolutely flavorful. I felt like the significant other would like a small snack after his meeting, so I got him a peanut butter jelly sandwich.... Which was really for me... You catch my drift, though.  

I sat outside and waited for him to call me. I people watch. Drivers honking. Beautiful men whom were not in my demographics running in short shorts... They're just pleasant to the eyes, I'm sorry. The server even came out to chat with me regarding my road trip to Humbolt County. She attended the college and was giving inside scoops on where to go. I'd definitely stop by again if I make another trip to San Francisco.... Because it was such a treat. People are nice. They are genuine. I like that. And delicious pastries.
author: Cici M.

description:
I have been coming to Brioche Cafe nearly every weekday for the past 5 years. I really like their House Blend coffee and Chai Lattes. When I feel like indulging, and if my Fitbit says it's okay, I will reward myself with a delicious dessert. The pan de chocolate, macarons, and sugar brioche are all extremely delicious. 

 The staff is very friendly to me and occasionally let me know about new desserts they'll soon introduce.
author: Justin M.

description:
I went here on a Sunday for lunch and the place was busy but we could get a table easily. Pro tip: they have outdoor seating for when it gets warmer. 

My boyfriend and I shared the French breakfast (baguette, butter and jam with a side of fruits) and the spinach and tomato quiche. I loved the quiche, it was thick, moist and delicious. 
The French breakfast wasn't great though. The baguette was pretty good, but the butter and jam weren't good for me. I like salted butter and theirs isn't and just doesn't have any taste. The jam probably isn't homemade and the fruits weren't fresh. 

Just FYI, their cappucino and hot chocolate have a lot of foam.

It's a nice little cafe and I will come back to try more of their pastries.
author: Coralie S.

description: I love Brioche Bakery. Every time I come to San Francisco's have to come here for breakfast. In my opinion it is the best drip coffee anywhere. I haven't personally tried too many dishes because I love the fruit danish and the croissant so much   My companions really like the individual quiche and the sandwiches look tasty
author: Kim M.

description:
Brioche Bakery felt like a poor mans version of La Boulange (/La Boulangerie... Or whatever they decided to call it). They have a fading and unreadable menu, and unappetizing looking sandwiches and quiches on display. I was disappointed after reading rave reviews - neither the baked goods nor the food was any good. 

* Chocolate Croissant - 3 stars: Mediocre, like La Boulange. 
* Breakfast Croissant Sandwich - 3 stars: chicken sausage and eggs on a croissant. I would rather have a BK croissanwich. 
* Avocado Scramble - 3 stars: again, mediocre and worse yet - the avocado wasn't ripe yet. 
* Fresh Squeezed OJ - 4.5 stars: exactly what it sounds like. The only good part of the meal!

It kind of reminded me of Crepe House / Squat and Gobble, except more expensive, smaller, and with fewer menu options.
author: Jess C.

description:
Came here for lunch today with a friend who recommended this place. Prior to coming, I looked at their website online and was excited because of all the cakes they offered! But when I walked into the store, they only had a few options for desserts on the bottom of the display case. Luckily they had the one that I wanted which was the opera cake! 

Food took a while to come because of what I assume was the lunch rush and they only had a few people working in the back with a small kitchen. Service was very friendly. My friend and I both told the person it was our first time and she recommended a few of their popular menu items. I ended up going with the mozzarella sandwich which is freshly sliced mozzarella, roma tomatoes, and pesto on ciabatta bread! Glad I took her recommendation because it tasted very good. The slices of mozzarella were SO big and the bread was definitely fresh. 

After finishing my sandwich, I tried the opera cake! It was tasty as well. Moist layers of cake with a kick of coffee taste as well to give me that taste of coffee that I needed without getting a cup of coffee. They also have brunch here! The eggs Benedict is next on my list to try here. 

All of their menu items are written on a chalkboard placed outside of the entrance as well as one menu inside that lists drinks located above the display case. There's also outdoor seating which I would definitely recommend if it's a nice day out and you enjoy people watching because it's located on a busy street and plenty of people walk by.
author: Cynthia T.

description: This is one of mine favorite salmon salad place in Bay area. Stuffs are very kind and helpfully.
author: Mr K.

description:
This was a quaint little bakery a few blocks away from China town, where we stayed. They had a small menu, but I think it was so they could really excel at what they do.
I got the chicken pot pie and a strawberry lemonade. The pot pie was quite amazing! The crust was so flaky and matched perfectly with the hot veggies and meat inside. I was impressed that they really filled that pie,  instead of it being mostly soup with some stuff thrown in. 
Their strawberry lemonade was good, but pretty seedy.
My husband got eggs benedict and that was also very delicious. The hollaindaise sauce was tangy and not too overpowering to the flavor of the eggs. It was a wonderful combination!
I would absolutely recommend this place to anyone looking for breakfast, brunch,  or lunch. You can eat quickly or take your time. It's a very flexible atmosphere.
author: Denae L.

description:
2.5-3 stars for what I purchased but rounding down for the grumpy servers. I'm always up for checking out new bakeries, so when I saw Brioche was nearby and you get a freebie for checking in, I decided to check it out. The freebie that particular month was a cup of coffee (not much more can be expected, I guess), and I also decided to give their Brioche (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=EHqmJ1bEnBACNzNBrvKSTg&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg) a try since they were sold out of a lot of other baked goods by 1pm on a Saturday. The brioche was pretty good but not amazing, but the worst part about stopping by here was the unfriendly staff. I felt like they gave me the evil eye for asking them about what my freebie was for checking in on Yelp, even though I ended up purchasing something after, and other people that I brought in ended up purchasing items too. 

This cafe is on the smaller side, so not that many tables and you'll be cozy with your neighbors. After this experience, I don't think I would return. Parking in this area can be tough since it always seems to be difficult to find a spot, even with a decent amount of street parking spots technically available.
author: Amy D.

description:
The quiche (quiches?) are the best. I love them like I love my mom's broccoli recipe (baked with mayonnaise, parmesan, and egg whites, Iowa-style). The Mushroom Quiche is so good: large, rich, comforting, and cheesy. Sounds like a too-good-to-be-true online dating profile, but it is oh so real.

Mushroom is my favorite, ham is 5 star as well. For the price point (just under $9), I like to get one and eat it for breakfast two mornings in a row. Also works for a lunch (just tried it with Frank's RedHot, delicious obvi), and once I even took a cold quiche to the airport. It didn't travel well, but halfway to Hong Kong I was still happily nibbling on my Brioche mushroom quiche!
author: Reb T.

description: Nice place to get a bite of brunch if you're in the little italy neighborhood. Strictly speaking this is a french bakery though. Got a quiche and the croque madame. Tasty brunch fare.
author: Sudipto G.

description:
Came here after we checked out of hotel but needed a place to hang out before we head to the airport. So walking around North Beach we found this little bakery/cafe. We weren't really hungry so it's caffeine time. 

They have their menu on a chalk board and you basically order at the counter and then they bring your food to your table. I'm into iced coffee now so I just ordered a Iced Mocha. Took a little while for the mocha to come out, but the lady apologized to us. They just got so busy and only a few people working in the back. That's okay cause we weren't in a hurry today.

Really good iced mocha. Not too bitter and they give you a nice big cup. Very satisfying overlooking Columbus street and watching the traffic go by. 

After awhile my wife got hungry and ordered their Grilled Chicken Salad. Hugh and looked really good. The salad had some Chinese noodles with so many vegetables. The dressing seemed like a homemade dressing which wasn't to sweet and had a tiny kick to it. Only downside to this salad  was the chicken. Seemed like they slices the chicken and then put is in the grill to make it into grilled chicken. Not a problem with that but it made the chicken really dry. Had to drink something to down the dry chicken. 

Nice little place with hot and cold sandwiches, pastries, and of course coffee. They have a very tiny kitchen in the back when making their food. Really enjoyed it and love checking out these little cafe in North Beach. Another great find.
author: Doug T.

description:
Decent little coffe/breakfast/lunch place located right in a super awesome patch of columbus right  coffee corner where columbus meets up with kearny. This stretch of columbus is well worth exploring as there are quite a few really nice eating and drinking places on this block.

As far as the parking goes it's street only, so like most things in this area it's best to ditch the car. 

There is both inside and outside seating, and the while the outside seating may not be the best choice before the morning chill burns off, it's a great choice later on. The inside seating ranges from larger tables/bench items (perfect for groups) to snug little two spots with great street views. The inside has lots of muted pastel coloring(blue and white for the counter area, amber/burnt orange type stuff for the seating area) with both natural and artificial light. It works to make a nice mellow effect. 

This place specializes in breakfast, especially and including quiche, which is a standout item. The coffee and chai options are good verging on great. The croissants are perfect. The other pastries are superior to what you'll find in many other like minded establishments. Other super awesome choices are the tartine(any of them) and the varuios sandwich choices. They do a mean panini. They also have some heavier choices such as omelette's et al. The service is better then I've come to expect in the area. They have a kind of ma and pop feel(the good kind of ma and pop that is) even though they aren't really a ma and pa kind of business. In the morning they seem to have a particular ability to listen to our fussy special ordering group was wanting. Well done Brioche.

Pricing? Yeah, well it's San Francisco. If you are eating and can keep it to a ten to fifteen dollar plate, you are making out like a bandit. Coffee and a sweet could run you 5-7 bucks depending on choices made.

Perfect for a cafe style light breakfast and coffee and/or a soup salad style lunch.
author: Steven W.

description: I had the breakfast croissandwich. It was fresh and hot and came with a nice salad. We also had the yogurt parfait which was delicious too.
author: Lauren D.

description:
Updating my review 4.5 years later!

Quaint cafe in the Broadway area borderlining Chinatown/North Beach. It's one of my favorite places to chill and people watch. It's a hidden gem as it's right across from the Coppolla building (what a beautiful view! :) I've ventured out here for lunch on weekdays as it's a slight getaway from the hustle & bustle of the FIDI. On the weekdays, it's fairly quiet and seating is easy to find. Kinda feels like a mini Parisian getaway.

Pretty sweet deal at $8-9 for a sandwich + side salad. My go-to is the poached pear salad - the greens are fresh and the candied pecans + cheese + dried blackcurrants with the pear is just.. perfection all around. They don't skimp on ingredients and it's fresh so I don't feel ripped off! I haven't tried their other lunch options since about 4 years ago when I last came so I can't fairly review those.
As for take-away/baked items, I tried a couple loaves of their bread, the sugar brioche, and tiramisu. All fairly priced and delicious! So many other sinful delights in the glass case I must try.. seems promising! Might just order catering for the office soon! The quiche looks freakin BOMB since it's baked in a puff pastry tart.. :0

The icing on the cake is the staff here is always super friendly and always readily available. I've taken some time ordering and they're always patient and non-judgmental :)
author: Emily C.

description: Good place for coffee and a bite to eat. Everything is fresh.  Try the molten lava cake!  We also use their awesome brioche bread for french toast.
author: Serena S.

description:
There are two things which set Brioche apart from any other run of the mill bakery. The first is that this is one of the few places in the city that you can actually buy those mini brioche buns which are perfect for making sliders. The second is their almond croissant. It doesn't look like much on the outside but once you have them heat it up and take a bite into it, it is amazing. It is completely filled with a sweet gooey almond filling which will start oozing out if you're not careful. Paired with a hot coffee this is a great way to start the day.

Overall, I appreciate Brioche bakery for both the quality croissant and the various brioche breads they offer. "I'm a fan."
author: Mark O.

description:
Y'know, I just need to have a real meal here. That's the bottom line. I mean sit down like a civilized person and have an herb omelet, a smoked salmon tartine, an endive salad or even a tuna sandwich. Perhaps all at the same time. Maybe wear a beret and an ascot and cradle my pet chihuahua Señor Wences in one hand and my fork at the ready in the other. But no, I often find myself walking down Columbus after satiating myself in North Beach likely with pasta or some other unnecessary carb, and that would be the very moment I find myself pondering a need to satisfy a sweet tooth.

A stop at the chaotic Stella Pastry didn't feel quite right nor waiting in the queue at Golden Gate Bakery. Nope, based on my last two visits, I have to say Brioche deserves to be more than an afterthought. The first time I came here was in the evening as the place was half-full with laptoppers and others having light bites for dinner. I was looking for something more decadent and had the $5 slice of the Lemon Pound Cake (photo: http://bit.ly/1ulHhf8) with a $3.25 Latte (photo: http://bit.ly/1BdsFU8). The cake was spongy-good and none too sweet, just the indulgence I wanted to end the day.

I returned months later with Jamie W. after a day out to see the Ai Weiwei art installation on Alcatraz. It was the middle of the afternoon, and the place was buzzing with customers. We decided to try their $1.75 house made Macarons, and sure enough, they are more substantive than the ones at Chantal Guillon and frankly much tastier, too with Salted Caramel and Chocolate particularly hitting the spot (photo: http://bit.ly/1xVzl4E). I took a gander at the Avocado Scramble on the next table and decided it was time to go savory next time. My only quibble? Space the tables out a bit more to avoid butt grazing, mine especially.

SWEETS - 4 stars...clearly house made goodies well turned
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...cute spot though I wish the tables weren't so crowded together
SERVICE - 4 stars...quite welcoming
TOTAL - 4 stars...graduating from sweet to savory in my bookmarks
author: Ed U.

description: Killer sugar brioche, good coffee, cozy ambience and above all, genuinely warm, kind staff.  This my regular go-to place in my hood. I always take my visitor friends here whenever I can!
author: Minna S.

description:
I was craving for macarons, I Yelped and found this spot. I tried the coffee, pistachio, french vanilla, creme brulee, raspberry and earl grey flavored macarons. 

I loved the pistachio, earl grey, raspberry and creme brulee one the best! I'll definitely come back to try the rest of the macaron flavors! 

$1.75 for one macaron.

I also ordered the strawberry lemonade and loved it too!

Extra friendly staff working here!
author: Alice X.

description:
The pastries at Brioche are AMAZING!! When I first walked in, I had no idea what I wanted. When I saw the selection of pastries in the window, I REALLY had no idea what I wanted. I was impressed by the size and variety. I finally narrowed my desired pastries to the fruit danish and the fruit tart, both of which looked irresistible... I picked the fruit tart.

I settled with my fruit tart and laptop at a small table by the door and got a few hours of work done. There were no electrical outlets (so thank goodness my laptop was near full charge) but the WiFi was fast and free so it worked out. There are restrooms here, and the service is wonderful. But the tart... oh man, the tart. I'm daydreaming about that tart. Next time I'll definitely try the croissant and fruit danish with a cup of their coffee. Love this place!
author: Stefanie C.

description: I had an ordinary experience. I tried the fruit, granola, yogurt cups and the OJ, both meh. Didn't finish the yogurt, it just turned into a mush with and a flatness to the yogurt so that was disappointing. I did sit here for a while and enjoy the wifi while I did some homework (with head phones on, it's super loud) I would recommend dining outside early on a Sunday  for a more pleasant experience, but they don't put out any planter boxes or partitions to shield you from the street or people walking on the sidewalk anymore so it wasn't that inviting.
author: Mona L.

description: Very clean, relaxed, bright place with good service and delicious, well-prepared food.  Good coffee.  Nice indoor/outdoor seating.
author: J E.

description:
Located in the little Italy area. Reviews of this place convinced us to give this place a try. Staff was quick to greet us. 

We elected to try the blueberry raspberry apricot pastry and a quiche. The quiche had to be warmed up, but worth the wait. Tomato, cheese, vegetables. The eggs mixture was soft. Crust was crisp. The pastry was large with a fair balance of sweetness from the fresh fruit topped upon. A good amount of fruit to the pastry. Not too much that it would fall off.

Good delicious and filling pastry, quick delivery and great execution. 
Bad nothing to date. 

Likely to visit again.
author: Denny T.

description: I was disappointed that an Italian cafe in SF North Beach could serve a very wet cappuccino--unless that's what someone explicitly asked for, which I didn't. But I can forgive this because my avocado scramble was delicious and perfectly cooked. (I hate nothing more than overcooked eggs!). Other pluses: cozy ambiance, wood tables and chairs, Italian music piping through, and an excellent view of Columbus Ave for people watching and just hanging out!
author: Stella L.

description: Great little café with outdoor seating between Little Italy and China Town. The French toast was amazing, with fresh fruit on top. Latte was top notch as well. My husband had the breakfast sandwich and he devoured it so I guess it was good. Overall cute coffee shop with great food and coffee.
author: Katherine L.

description:
Very cute and good for chatting with friends place.
I wanna come back for my happy moments.

Here are my reviews!
Quiche with Salad is homemade goody.
Cheesecake is really tasty.
Opera cake is moist and ligers on!
Lemon tart is okay.
author: Kurumi O.

description: This is a nice quaint little coffee shop the Avocado sample was delicious, just a little under seasoned, and the coffee was nice and strong, it's the perfect place to people watch.
author: April M.

description:
One of my favorite places in SF. Everyone is super nice, and the atmosphere is a 10/10.

The Brioche Bread Pudding is ridiculous (pro tip: ask for whipped cream on it too :)).
author: David B.

description: Came here for brunch. Maybe we just ordered the wrong thing. The egg dishes were nah. Half the plate was barely cooked potatoes. However the cafe environment is great. Great music. Might come back and try the desserts.
author: Jessica S.

description: OMG, this little place is awesome! The sandwiches are amazing. I had the roasted chicken sandwich. It came with the best tasting chicken and baguette. I'm going back the next time I'm in San Francisco. It's a cute little cafe with an awesome staff. Well located for a quick drop off when using Uber. Which is super common in the city.
author: Yanette R.

description:
I had breakfast here one day.  Apparently I arrived too early on morning as there was no one available at the counter for about 5 minutes. We then had to request menus to get the meals we had expected.  I'm going to guess this cafe does most of its food sales in to go pastries.

We ordered basic breakfasts including a brioche French toast and the avocado scramble. I had a well made cappuccino made the way a good Italian might expect. Overall we had a satisfying, but not a standout meal.
author: Robert D.

description:
Came here to pick up some breakfast on our way to a tour for my boyfriend and I. The cashier was extremely nice and put up with my constant changing decisions of what to get. I finally decided to get the spinach and mushroom quiche, brioche muffin and a chocolate croissant as well as some fresh squeezed orange juice.

The mushroom quiche was amazing! It was cooling and had just come out of the oven when I decided to purchase it. It wasn't too salty, nice and eggy with plenty of fresh mushrooms. It also came with a side salad. So good! 

The brioche muffin was a tad bit dry. I should've stayed with the apple crumble muffin that I first chose but what can I say? I thought they were known for brioche so I decided to give it a try. Eh. 

The chocolate croissant was good but just a typical chocolate croissant. 

I didn't get to try their other breakfast items because we were in a hurry but if I had the chance I would! You should definitely get the quiche and try their fresh squeezed orange juice! You won't regret it!
author: Tiffany W.

description: Ordered the avocado scramble and almond croissant. I requested to add the spicy sausage but it didn't come with my meal and the avocado were slightly brown. The almond croissant never came either because it got burnt and it was the last one. The guy suggested the brioche instead, which was ok, and end up getting the chocolate almond croissant which was also just ok -- prob should've just asked for a refund.
author: Christine C.

description: Super yummy croissants & pastries! The orange juice tastes so fresh you'd think you were eating an orange and the eggs Benedict were cooked to perfection! The French toast is great although I would ask for the berry syrup on the side it's a little sweeter than I care for. They're so fluffy, fresh and airy. My kids split an order and it was plenty! We will definitely be back!
author: Christin F.

description:
Short Story:
We came here on a Saturday afternoon in search for coffee.  It was pretty good!

Long Story:
We got to the city early before our reservations at The House and were a bit tired.  So, we came here for a Latte and was fairly impressed.  The place was pretty quiet with lots of windows.  The price was fair for what you pay in SF too.  They also had a good selection of pastries to choose from.

Verdict:
I'll remember this place and come back if I'm in the same area.
author: Michael W.

description:
Honestly, Chinatown is among the last places you would expect to find the perfect French cafe, but this review is testimony that Brioche proves otherwise.  C'est drole, n'est-ce que pas?

[BACKGROUND]

I was on my way home looking for a place to get lunch, and all other places I passed by seemed too crowded, too expensive, and/or too generic.  

I must be developing good Yelpy instincts because I chose Brioche purely by storefront impressions, without any consultations with technology whatsoever.  And what do you know, when I consult Yelp after the fact, it turns out I had spotted a 4.5 with my naked eye ;)

[AMBIANCE]

Authentically French in every sense, except it's quite small given that we're in SF after all.  Besides the somewhat cramped size, it's a charming cafe.  The interior is homey and cozy, furnished and decorated like a kitchen and dining room.  The European feel extends to the exterior with the classic scalloped blue fabric awning.  It's even complete with wicker patio furniture and carefree customers sipping coffee, reading newspapers, and people watching.

Some people ahead of me complained about service, but I thought it was fine.

[FOOD]

Niçois sandwich, $7.75 (Mediterranean style tuna salad with extra virgin olive oil, fresh tomatoes, lettuce and chipotle spread on our crusty baguette): I'm extremely picky with sandwiches, but this was pretty close to perfect.  All the ingredients were fresh, and the baguette was fluffy and tasted truly homemade.  All those chain stores that claim to have artisan bread baked fresh daily blah blah blah now appear to be quackery in comparison to Brioche.  Also, it comes with a side salad!  Also fresh and I suspect it's organic.

Spinach and Gruyère Omelet, $11.50 (sautéed organic baby spinach and onions with Gruyère cheese, served with oven roasted rosemary potatoes and artisan organic whole wheat toast): One of the rare places where you can get a wholesome, satisfying brunch without lapsing into food coma afterwards.  The omelet has a nice, thin layer of egg, and they pleasantly don't overdo the cheese.  The potatoes are just the right portion (digging this continued European theme with the European portions), unlike the disgusting heaping pile of fried potatoes at most American brunches.  I really liked the toast, which is on homemade bread (in a beautiful homemade shape, I might add).  It even came with a few pieces of fruit, which was refreshing to finish with.

[CONCLUSION]

I was planning to come for an epic marathon cafe work session, but I didn't get much done.  Perhaps it's the relaxing atmosphere at this charming cafe, whose recurrent European theme predominates over the American workaholic mentality.
author: Edna C.

description: Treat yourself to this delightful cafe and bakery.  The food is fresh and delicious, and served in very generous portions. We had the brioche French toast, the quiche, and the French Breakfast. Everything was served piping hot, with very pleasing presentation.  Sit inside or outside, and see the world pass by on Columbus. The staff and the owner are very friendly and accommodating.
author: Nancy S.

description: Food was AWESOME! Reasonable prices. And they have MIMOSAS!! Good location and was really close to our hotel. Didn't have to wait too long for my food. Worth checking out.
author: Aspen L.

description:
Great little spot. 

This place is super cute and yummy. it's very casual, first come first serve seating. The food is fresh and really reasonably priced -- and they have great breakfast and lunch options. Definitely worth checking out.
author: Stephanie M.

description: My mom and I were thrilled when we took a bite out of their spinach and tomato quiche. We don't typically like quiches, but Brioche Bakery and Cafe serves exquisite, fluffy, savory quiches. We also loved their Prosciutto with pear, avocado, and honey drizzle tartine - It was light and oh-so-delicious. Latte and chai had beautiful foam and tasted amazing too. Service was quick and friendly :] Thank you for such a wonderful breakfast!
author: Jenny C.

description: Cafe Puccini is out of commission because of a fire. Cafe Roma has changed personnel and, apparently, coffee. (If you wonder, Cafe Trieste is a venerable icon with nice baked goods but lackluster espresso.) There's need for a new North Beach star and, for me, that's Brioche. Not the specific bread itself, because the Cafe offers a variety of better, more substantial staples. Most important, Brioche provides a deep, smoky espresso. And, for those of you with iron willpower (or a desire to indulge), very tempting and tasty pastries.
author: Bruce B.

description: Italian feeling here. Capuchino and iced latte are very Italian. The place is cozy and chilled. Comes here if you want to be chilled with some coffee.
author: Tran M.

description: Perfect little cafe. Brunch was great, it wasn't crowded and the atmosphere was relaxed. Exactly what I was looking for.
author: Sharon M.

description: Egg Benedict was wonderful you'd want it twice  .. lasagna was horrible and makes you regret waking up and having breakfast .. overall four star
author: Marten P.

description: The location of this place is fantastic in Little Italy. Their coffee is good. Their croissants can be better though.
author: Ahmad A.

description:
3/6 review - Lovely pastries - croissants, BRIOCHE pastry was pretty awesome!, They have great  coffee and beautiful looking deserts; didn't try more than the brioche but the Tiramisu looked fabulous. .... The staff was pleasant as well :)

I returned to get the Tiramisu, too good for words :D
author: Tere C.

description:
The cashier was utter chaos and totally confusing because there is only a handful of menus at the counter.  We couldn't look at the menu until it was almost our turn because the people in front of us were holding onto them.  

The two breakfast entrees we ordered were bland, mediocre, and definitely overpriced (!!!) for the quality of food. Unfortunately, NOTHING really stood out or special about the Breakfast Croissant ($8.95) and Avocado Scramble ($11.50).  If you are looking for some delicious brunch on a Sunday morning, then this place is really just, eh-OK.  I was a bit disappointed to say the least, definitely not returning if the quality of food does not improve, sad. 

Check out the pics posted by Jess C. on 12/13/2015.  We had the exact same items minus the chocolate croissant.  I should have paid more attention to the pics and reviews next time prior to our next visit to a brand new place.  :O
author: Vicky H.

description: Cool place to hang out. Tiramisu is my all time favorite here. Service is great price are fair...
author: James D.

description: The girl who take my order was super friendly and order an Italian soda but she did not give the remaining soda water for my drink which was super syrupy..Afterward, I had approach the counter and I ask the guy with the slick back hair for more soda water- he was rude and unpleasant. If you are going to work in a bakery you should pleasant with your customers.  Which he was not happy nor cared about his career. Therefore, If you want good service please avoid this guy.
author: Teresa C.

description:
Any self respecting person who values his time should go here for breakfast. The food is good, the price is reasonable and the wait is short. The service is good as well and the place is reasonably clean considering that it is a high tourist area. There are other places nearby with slightly better food and ambiance but the lines are long and the food is pricey.

If you could only order one item, get yourself the brioche french toast. It is very good.
author: Vin A.

description: While the croissants and food were absolute wonderful perfection, service was completely terrible. Rude, no personality, had to repeat myself many times, and if they don't understand what you're saying, they say it back in a condescending way. When we got our food, halfway through I realized they forgot my cake to go, I went back for it and she practically tossed it over the counter and said "here's your cake". Customer service is everything, and then number one reason people will not come back. Seems no one knows what they're doing and the service was also slow.
author: Lauren G.

description:
French toast and eggs Benedict were both prepared and served well.   French toast was moist and delicious.  Benedict was a little undersized, but yolk was cooked perfectly.

Good for a quick bite on a Saturday morning.

$27 for 2 - not bad
author: Vince R.

description:
I love this bakery and cafe!!!  

They have the best bakery items I have ever tried!  Even though it may be pricey for their selections, it is definitely worth every penny!

Their blueberry tart looks so delectable to the eye and scrumptious to the palate!

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/QQwsy-M3O5w6FSPaVFJ3uQ?userid=I-FmdvI28N7OIIt4JZOgIg#iLhu7hfq_AzqaZzcP0hdcw

Their croissant is nice and fluffy and not only filled with buttery goodness, but also with some yummy filling inside!  It's great. Period.

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/QQwsy-M3O5w6FSPaVFJ3uQ?userid=I-FmdvI28N7OIIt4JZOgIg#hVRXkSBYQqHUUug82d9F-Q

Their hazelnut tart is very nutty and rich with chocolate! 

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/QQwsy-M3O5w6FSPaVFJ3uQ?userid=I-FmdvI28N7OIIt4JZOgIg#6AkATygV5i2jmHLHYeELOQ

Their cappuccino is frothy and I topped it off with sprinkles of chocolate!

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/QQwsy-M3O5w6FSPaVFJ3uQ?userid=I-FmdvI28N7OIIt4JZOgIg#qnOLiyIaeL_WEPWKmOdR_w

The layout is cozy and they have Wi-Fi!  

Final say - Food, coffee, Wi-Fi, lounge, atmosphere and good service is all there!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
The setting of this place is perfect, almost out of a movie. It's conveniently located near an intersection with a great view, the staff here is awesome, they let us stay for a long period of time while chatting about current events and old times.

From a distance you can see Coppola's old movie studio (not certain if it's still operating). The ambiance is perfect for any occasion. Most of all are the selections of items available. Although I was not fortunate to try their pastries or bread...was still full from the previous spot. 

But as you gaze behind the counter, the staff is busy making the brioche. Quite entertaining for the non baker person.  Drinks were good and reasonably priced. If you are in the area, this is a great little spot to hit up while exploring this side of town.
author: Enrique G.

description: Pecan tart & opera cake were both delicious. Great coffee. Very friendly service. Really enjoyed our visit!
author: Jenna M.

description:
I would not eat here again and neither should you. 

First of all, before I go any further into explaining my terrible meal, let me explain how the two staples of any bakery and cafe, the bread and coffee, utterly failed. 

Stale bread. Yes, the baguette that held my sandwich was stale. No place that purports to be a bakery should serve stale bread. Fresh bread is not just a hope I have when I order something at a bakery, it's an expectation. And they failed to meet it. 

Next is the coffee. My latte was bland. No bueno at all. 

Now that I've established how this place fails at what it purports to be, I'll move on to tell you about my meal. That sucked too. 

I ordered the prosciutto sandwich. They put clumps of brie cheese on it, so that when I ate it I would either bite into a huge chunk of brie that overpowered the whole sandwich, or just bite a portion of sandwich with no cheese on it at all. They should have cut the cheese thinner and spread it more. 

And the meat was old too. I ate a piece of the prosciutto on its own, because I can just eat that meat itself since it's so good, and I realized the meat was old and going bad. Its coloration had browned and it was very off in flavor. So they basically served me rotting meat that could have gotten me sick. 

Do yourself a favor and don't eat here.
author: Aiden S.

description:
Had a solid huge croissant and an excellent creamy sweet chai here, and the staff are very friendly. Not a bad place to work here; there's at least one pair of outlets in the corner by the window.
Wifi: Good ping, 6.8 down / 0.9 up.
author: Linus W.

description:
Went to city on president's day and decided to try out this small eatery on Columbus.  4 and a half star on yelp so why not it was still early so I decided to have the French toast.  It was very tasty but the portion was small so if you go need to pair the French toast with something else.  

Took two pastries a lemon and a pear tart and they were very good even after a couple of hours.  

With so many other places to check out in the city not sure I will make another visit soon, unless I am near china town and want something different.

Overall 4 star experience might of been a bit better if I tried something different.
author: Mike M.

description:
Brioche Bakery & Cafe is a jewel in the heart of North Beach. Personally, I'm a fan of the Chai Latte. I been living in SF for the past year and Brioche has become my go-to place. The personnel is kind and responsive, specially the morning shift employees (there is a member of the staff, working during afternoon and evening hours that is not as helpful).The tables and common areas are clean and great for meet-ups and working remotely. As I said before, the chai! Try the chai! 

Hope this helps!
author: Annette O.

description:
Nice cafe.  They were kind enough to accommodate us to dine in even though it was almost 30mins before closing time.

We tried their chocolate souffle and cannoli.  The chocolate souffle was a hit with the kids and adults. Not too sweet. I like the gooey chocolate in the middle.

The cannoki had a strong after taste to it. Maybe we're just not used to the flavor that they put it. My hubby still ate it all up :)

This is a nice cozy cafe that brings you a parisian/italian cafe feel within close proximity to the Chinese cafes in Chinatown.
author: Rochelle 'Shella' T.

description: I can't believe I haven't gotten around to reviewing this place! I often have to come into the city for work - one day I was in the area for work and was looking for breakfast at 1pm. I stumbled on this place and it has been my go to for a late breakfast every time I'm in the city. I am convinced they have the best croissants in the entire Bay Area - flakey, buttery, light and fabulous heated up. I always opt for the breakfast croissant sandwich - but their croissants go fast! I've tried quite a few other things on their menu and am always completely satisfied with my choices. The food always seems fresh and absolutely delicious. I love the cute atmosphere it has right off Columbus and parking surprisingly actually usually isn't horrible! It tops my top 10 places I love. The service is always friendly and I always leave a happy customer. Thank you Brioche!! :)
author: Callan B.

description:
Fun hang! 
No rush to leave.
Yummy tiramisu and iced mocha.
Scrambled eggs with avocado were good.
It's not a high end place...I'm an SF native and I feel comfortable here.
author: Ramani C.

description:
Wonderful establishment and very kind staff. I witnessed a server patiently use Google to translate  some dishes to a pair of tourists. Another server offered a free pastry to a customer who mentioned today is her birthday. 

Their croissants are amazing! I can't wait to go back to try more items in their menu.
author: S B.

description:
I came in here on a Sunday morning for coffee and croissant. The croissant was like you get at Safeway or Costco. Nothing special at all. Pretty mediocre. This isn't a serious bakery like a Thorough, Tartine, Arizmendi, etc. The croissant probably came from a food service delivery truck.

What I hated most was the LOUD Mexican music playing from the radio in the kitchen. It was like a damned taqueria. It destroyed the ambiance.

The place *looks* like a nice cafe. That is what brings in the tourists. That's all you need to succeed in the tourist part of town, unfortunately.

The cooked breakfast may be fine. I don't know.
author: Chuck G.

description: Everything looks so delicious, their bread, sandwiches, sweets, brioches, quiche, just to name a few. If I could I would eat here every morning and/or lunch time. Very European atmosphere ads coziness to this place. In addition to great look, taste, they are very nice to their customers. Next time I'm in SF I'll be back here.
author: Agnes K.

description:
Well, I should start off that I am a brunch fanatic, who loves bakeries so obviously this was going to start off good for me.  Especially if I can have brunch on a weekday, while I get some work done - Yes, please!! 
I was in the area for work and was looking to grab a quick breakfast and coffee before my meeting started.  I came across Brioche Bakery on Yelp and remembered I had seen this cute little place before, and wanted to try it. 
The staff was courteous (though not overly friendly).  I had a soy latte (good) and the spinach and tomato quiche.  The quiche was AMAZING!! It isa personal quiche, in a to die for pastry, with onions and the pErFeCt texture!!!! It came with a small side salad. DELICIOUS :)
The bakery is small, with about 10 two person tables, and has free wifi. 
Highly recommend you check it out!
author: Sarah F.

description: Yesterday was my second time visiting Brioche Bakery and Cafe. I can't help but be drawn to it. It's a cute little joint right in all of the madness of Chinatown and Little Italy. Parking can be hard, but not impossible. This time around, I only had a latte (which was excellent!). But the first time I tried this place out, I had the avocado egg scramble. Absolutely delicious. The food is fresh and tasty and comes with a side of fresh fruit. The restaurant is clean and the employees are very friendly.
author: Christina B.

description: I pretty much never write reviews, but am making an exception now. The food is really good in here. I've ordered a mushroom quiche, avocado scramble, almond croissant, macaroons - everything was consistently good. A bit pricey, but worth it.
author: Karina R.

description:
Multiple visits

French cafe in Chinatown? Yep! A darn good one with very friendly service. It's on Columbus just across the street from Chinatown, at the crossroad of Financial District and Little Italy. I've been here numerous times when I'm in the area and I've always enjoyed a nosh or a meal.

I'm mostly gluten-free so I can only hear the praises on their home-made almond croissants, chocolate croissants and other pastries. I did try their brioche and plain croissant and they are not any less delicious than those in Paris. 

My favorite is the Niçoise Salad ($12). Not a fan of olives, but I absolutely love the dijon mustard vinaigrette with a hint of olives. Mixed greens topped with fresh ahi tuna poached in herbed olive oil, haricot verts, fingerling potatoes, hard-boiled egg. A perfect lunch. 

Poached Pear Salad ($9) is my other choice. I usually skip the blue cheese. The mixed green is topped with poached pear, currants, candied walnuts, cherry tomatoes, and tossed with maple basil orange vinaigrette.

Coffee/espresso are French roast. I've always enjoyed sitting here with a book on weekends. It's a little patch of France in a busy neighborhood. They also cater.
author: Matt Y.

description: First time visiting SF and this cafe was the last plave we went to eat before we left amd by far it was amazing. Service and food were awesome. Even took some almond crossiants back home.
author: Elvira V.

description: I always check to see if Brioche has any of their house made tiramisu (I feel like it's one of the best of north beach) Its so relaxing to sit down inside with my dessert and a cup of tea next to the window and watch all the people go by on columbus. I've been here too many times to count!
author: Babebaby Z.

description:
The food was fine, nothing superb. Your standard local brunch spot.

Have to say - we got in at 2:55pm (brunch ends at 3pm. I even called to check) and they initially wouldn't serve us brunch. I had a GiltCity deal and had FINALLY planned to get out to North Beach to use it so I begged and begged.. and they finally served us our brunch! Though I was a little iffy on some of the details.. the "pastry" was limited to just the cookies/muffins, not their really fancy looking pastries. (aren't those what theyre known for??"

* Brioche french toast - 3 stars
(w/ strawberries, strawberry glaze, & raspberries)
This was decent - but the toast was too soft, no crisp to it!

* Prosciutto sandwich - 3 stars
Fine, average. Like any other prociutto sandwich (hard french bread, just a couple pieces of meat, cheese)

* Fudge cookie - 3.5 stars
Nice. Moist, dense, and soft.

* Chocolate chip muffin - 4 stars
Also really nice, but a little oily.
author: Ziyan C.

description: Fantastic cafe. Wish we went here for breakfast first. We ordered a house coffee and a pear tart. The best tart I've ever had and the coffee far surpassed any coffee I've ever had too. All for $8.00 and I think the coffee is free refill. Definitely going back for lunch sometime.
author: Tong C.

description:
Nice spot on Colombus with a great variety of food - pastries & desserts, but also salads, sandwiches, omelets, special brunch items on the weekend.

I had an iced coffee (standard) and a  salad that had mixed greens, rice noodles, carrots, cucumber, sprouts, chicken and a peanut coconut vinagrette. Very unique and tasty! 

Staff was very friendly too. Small outdoor tables too, which I love.
author: MaryKate M.

description:
Honestly, while I didn't think it was amazing, I did have a good experience. 

We stumbled in, after finding out the other restaurant we were heading to was closed, the menu is honestly confusing because they say that certain things aren't served except on the weekend but the lady at the front said we could order anything. 

I ordered the spinach omelet and I was pretty satisfied with the food. The eggs were very fluffy and everything tasted and was seasoned well. The potatoes they came with was delicious and the fruit was nice but there were a couple of sketchy looking pieces. I also ordered the fruit tart were was lovely but the custard that was located directly next to the tart shells looked like they solidified, which is kinda weird. 

Other then that they food was decent and so were the prices. 

The service was pretty good as well, the lady at the front was very helpful and polite. While I don't think it's a true 4 stars, it wouldn't be fair to give them 3 stars. They were more like a 3.5 stars.
author: Janice C.

description: Fruit tart was fresh and good the triple choolate mousse left a little to be desired prices reasonable for the city.
author: M A.

description:
Brioche is a solid cafe. It has the typical ordering counter with the specials listed and the window display of deserts.  Six tables inside and 4 outside. There is a large window so you don't need to sit outside to people watch. 
I ordered the BLTA at the recommendation of the staff. (This is a good practice...ask the bartender what he/she can make well, ask the restaurant staff what they make well.)  Great, flavorful sandwich. And, it's enough to split with a friend. I also ordered the French Onion Soup. FOS is a favorite of mine if done well. This version was 'OK'. On the plus side, there was not the overload of salt. But on the minus, it could have used more flavor. I would say it had a delicate flavor ehich was actually good. 
I also ordered and espresso. Very solid. However, it would be nice to have zest. I didn't ask, so maybe this is available?
Again, a solid three star, very close to a four star.
author: George S.

description:
For such a small cafe, they definitely have a lot of brunch choices on their menu.

I have tried their Prosciutto Tartine which includes avocado, pear and honey and a side salad. I overlooked the honey on the menu, it was a sweet tartine...when I wanted something savory. The honey definitely covered up the savoriness of the prosciutto. Their salad was pretty good. I should have ordered their salads instead.

Overall it wasn't a bad experience coming here. They have some interesting things on their menu. Also, they're all of decent price.
author: Annie H.

description: I stopped in here while I was on vacation because I had read that they made a great chai latte. Definitely ranks as one of the best I've had, creamy and not too sweet.
author: Nicole B.

description: A fantastic little spot on the skirts of Chinatown. Freshly baked goods that stand out in a city of food. Great people, coffee, and sandwiches. If you're nearby, or even far away, take the time and stop in. The chocolate croissants are buttery, flaky, and truly fantastic. Get in, and be happy.
author: Maureen A.

description: One word. Quiche. The best you'll ever eat. My girl friend and I were looking at a wedding venue and we had some time to kill so we were walking to find a place to eat. And found this place. First I did order something else. I saw someone order a quiche and thought y not. My god I was so thankful that I ordered. It's the best quiche we ever tasted. Ofc other stuffs are good too. But quiche. Oh yeah.
author: Sayed A.

description: The staff is really nice. The sandwich I got was disappointing, especially for being so simple. I got a roast chicken panini. The bread and chicken were so bland. Perhaps I would try something else, but definitely not this sandwich again. Blech.
author: Tiffany M.

description:
5 starts because I can't put 6 stars.

For the time being the only place I have found where you can eat delicious non-sweet snacks.
Maybe the sweets are as good but I am in love with all the non-sweet snacks they create in this beautiful small place.
It really brought memories from french bistros and all the good stuff that you can taste all day long in Europe.

The service was perfect!

My perfect means: 
The girl who served us was smart, she understood jokes, she didn't come to ask us every 5 minutes if everything is good.

I will go there again and again and again
author: Antony T.

description:
Service here was fast and friendly. It's a cute cafe and it's clean. I ordered the almond croissant and it was delicious. 
I would recommend this place. It has a great atmosphere and it's quiet enough that you can read a book or do some work on your laptop (did I mention they have free wifi).
author: sabrina r.

description: There's nothing hot or panini like about their hot grilled chicken panini.... I asked if they pressed it and they said yes.... I got it home.... No pressing AT ALL... The bread was soft just like they microwaved cheese on it...: I'm not just being picky this sandwich didn't even come close to a panini press.... Very disappointed
author: Chris T.

description: I got the grilled cheese and soup special. When the plate came out I thought the the grilled cheese was a little small and they made me a 2nd one right away. The soup was French onion and with all the bread in the soup it really was enough food without the 2nd sandwich! I can admit when I'm wrong. Every thing was very good and now I have a snack for later!
author: Carinna M.

description: Their avocado scramble is fire, this is my new favorite spot for breakfast, their orange juice is very fresh and the prices are very reasonable.
author: Liza G.

description:
The services here are efficient and the guys working here are friendly. Props because they have macaroons available (for the past two times I came in).

I have yet to try other menu items, an edit will be available once I do so.

An absolutely nice spot for a French bakery. It is within walking distance to Chinatown and North Beach.
author: Bennett W.

description: Really disappointing, nothing interesting with the food, and slow service. A disservice for the neighborhood.
author: Ming Z.

description: I can stop drinking coffee now, I've found the best cup in the city: the cafe creme at Brioche. Yeah, it's made with cream, not milk, but that's no different than Philz. Except Philz uses it to hide terrible coffee--this was an exquisite layering of rich dark coffee (not bitter-harsh like at the beautiful rich-bitch of a cafe next door) with a creaminess that wasn't too concentrated. I'm laying awake at 5 am still thinking about it. Did I mention it's damn strong? Maybe I really should stop drinking coffee.
author: Be F.

description: Pet peeve - cold toast, cold butter. Its like you are just trying to annoy me. Underwhelmed.
author: Daniel W.

description:
Not a coffee hound but this was mild and delicious.  Wife liked her tea but her grilled guyere sandwich was not melted through.  Son enjoyed his sandwich and seconds on cocoa.  The sugar brioche was devine but too subtle for sons young palette.

I had their signature dessert.   Can't recall name but hints of coffee flavor.  Very delicate but lacked flavor to me, despite the layered artistry of the baking.

Nice little tables outside.  Good quiet meeting place where we met a friend on the inside.
author: Bob J.

description: Great Saturday morning option for early rising tourists looking for more than a doughnut. The quiche is great, as is the brioche.
author: Luke H.

description:
We came here Sunday morning to pick up some breakfast on the way to a trip. Right as we entered, two people walked in and so we let them go ahead before us. That group of 2 turned into 12 and pretty soon we had 12 dishes being made before they got to ours. I understand it's not their fault but I would've appreciated it if they could have taken our order for cooking before the giant party. 

Anyway, onto the food. Pretty decent taste overall. We got the avocado omelette, the Brioche French toast and the grilled vegetable sandwich. The French toast was definitely the best part of the order. The taste was decent but overall nothing was blow-my-mind-away. Also, the portion sizes were a little small for the price. Overall, not a bad place to come by to if you need breakfast in the north beach area!
author: Saumya S.

description: I fell in love with brioche here.  That creamy crusty goodness makes you a believer.  They have a handful of offerings at a time and they're all great.  Even their side salads have just the right dressing.  The fruit is fresh and assorted.  The spinach omelette has generous amounts of fresh spinach.  I can't believe my kids liked the herb in the potatoes and eggs.  Woo hoo! Another winner!
author: Susannah K.

description:
Had their individual quiche to go.
It was very good.
Nice custard texture and taste.
Worth coming back and try their other items
author: S.K. Y.

description:
Brioche bakery offers french pastry, sammies, coffee, etc.  in a very small setting(just a few tables for sitdown).

eats: panini (premade, 7.75)
-cheddar cheese, lots of turkey meat, lettuce, tomato, garlic aioli on ciabatta bread
large sammie, tummy very happy/fulfilled.
-good value for amount given.

brew: java & ethiopian, sf. coffee co, (L.2)
-smooth, midde roast,

crumbs:
-serviece quick, courteous, with smiles all the way.
author: Victor G.

description: Very authentic French bakery. We tried breakfast Croissant and French breakfast. Sour cream matches perfectly with baguette. Not easy to be competitive close to china town. They are doing well.
author: Yilan L.

description:
NOT TO CONFUSE WITH CREPE & BRIOCHE AT THE FARMERS MARKETS.  THEY ARE NOT RELATED.  I see a lot of pictures here that belong to a completely different, awesome bakery that has booths at the many bay area markets.  I love their stuff too!  

I stop by Brioche Bakery whenever I'm in the area.  I usually grab a buttery yummy croissant and a coffee to go.  Recently, I dined in for the Eggs Benedict. It was soooo good!  The location is convenient, but parking can be a problem.  Nice friendly staff here too. I can't wait to visit again!
author: A. M.

description:
I walk by Brioche Bakery & Cafe everyday on the way to work and I have to fight every inner gluttonous urge I have to stop by for a freshly baked croissant. 

The smell of freshly baked pastries in the morning is such a treat and the plain croissants here are such a light, buttery, and flaky delight. No jam needed for me. I eat the croissants plain and they are just yummy on their own. Lunchtime sandwiches are pretty good too even if you're having a grab and go sandwich. I like the sandwich with the black forest ham and Swiss cheese but the kicker is the fig bread. It's a wonderful combination of flavors. The sweetness of the bread melds with the savory meat and nutty cheese in every bite. 

Weekend brunches are a laid back affair here. Unlike other popular brunch places, there is little hustle and bustle here. Take a seat and relax. Be warned if you're trying to rush, this is not the place. Brunch service is slow! But otherwise kick back and enjoy a smoked salmon tartine (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/QQwsy-M3O5w6FSPaVFJ3uQ?select=GJWRNv8NYIBFyQGRznz6gg) and ice coffee under the sun if it's a lovely day. It's such a simple open faced sandwich but combination of flavors from the smoked salmon, herbed crème fraîche, shallots, chives, and capers are spot on. 

Brioche Bakery & Cafe is cute little French bistro that keeps it simple, but does it right. If you want to slow it down just for a little, stop by to take a breather, have some coffee and pick a pastry. You'll enjoy it before you know it.
author: Jon L.
