Simply the best muffin in town. 
If you get a chance, try the Mocha Muffin, oooohhhh absolutely yummy. Love the owners as well!
author: Raquel F.

description:
I work right around the corner and in my mind, this place was only a breakfast/pastry shop.  But one day as I was walking by I noticed a lunch crowd, so I stopped in.

Wonderful sandwiches and you can't beat the price for the quality.  One day they were sampling a soup which was pretty amazing too.  Brioche has seen me a lot for lunch since that discovery.  The only thing keeping me from eating there every day is my judgemental friend Mr. Bathroom Scale.

PS - I work in Jackson Square... not around the OTHER corner where all the nakedness is... just felt the need to mention...
author: Mariko H.

description: Brioche never disappoints: lunch, afternoon pick me up, or food for a work event. I also love the fact that you can sit outside and enjoy the San Francisco bustle while sipping your chai latte and noshing on your yummy treats.
author: Happy D.

description:
This is a fantastic family run cafe!
I live a block from a Starbucks but walk the 10 minutes to come here!
I would support a small cafe any day over a chain...and this one for sure!
From the moment you walk in you are greeted with friendly smiles and great service!
Free wireless Internet!
The first time I came in I ordered only an Americano, sat at a table and worked on my computer for at least 2 hours- not feeling rushed to leave at all. 
The food is beautiful, French authentic, delicious and affordable!
another bonus- Natural Sunlight and out door seating in the sun!!

Everyone must give Brioche a try- you'll be hooked!

Bon Appetit!
author: Claudine D.

description: My friends and I just stopped by quickly after landing super early in SF.  We hadn't heard of this cafe before, but it looked promising since it was cute and we wanted actual food instead of coffeeshop food next door.  They have fresh squeezed orange juice, which was awesome cuz places rarely do that anymore, and I had the grilled chicken hot panini with lemon-thyme marinade and avocado, which was really good!  My only warning is that this sandwich is a bit on the big side.  I shared with a friend so it was perfect, but even if I were starving, I would be uncomfortably full if I ate that entire sandwich by myself.  Damnit... now I'm craving one and I'm back in LA.  Oh, sad day..
author: Cyndi B.

description:
I was in the neighborhood when suddenly my stomach growled. I wanted to get something sweet. And when I finally able to control my urge for stella's tiramisu and sacripantina, I chose to go here.

After walking for a couple of blocks, I was disappointed because they didn't have anymore almond croissant. The server sense my disappointment and recommended something similar to the almond croissant. It was like a pie with raspberry jam hidden underneath the filling kind of. It was great but it didn't blow me away when I think about it again now. So, 3 stars.

I'm gonna try the almond croissant in the future and may update my review
author: Cliff T.

description: The almond croissant is very good (see my photo).  They have a booth at the Sunnyvale Farmer's market on Saturdays.
author: Scott F.

description:
I got there and sat outside on their awesome patio.  The sun was incredible.  My ice tea was pretty decent, of a mint variety.

My veggie sandwich, although on awesome bread, was very ho-hum.  Nothing too exciting or amazing about it.  I wish it had more panache or gumption.  Instead it was toeing the line like all the other ho-hum veggie sandwiches in the world.

I couldn't believe people were sitting inside, it was too damn hot in there.
author: Pouria Y.

description: I have to update my review because the owner actually responded to my review the last time I was in there.  We talked about how I used to work in a coffee shop, and she even asked for recommendations on how to keep the coffee refreshed without wasting it all.  So, Go You, Brioche Bakery, for giving two licks what people are saying about you.  And also, for keeping Diet Snapple Peach Tea in stock ever since I've been asking for it.
author: Lindsay S.

description:
I stopped in here with my friend after lunch in the middle of the afternoon. We ordered a raspberry tart to share and also a lava cake. I also tried a cup of coffee (I believe it was the Ethiopian blend). 

I REALLY enjoyed the lava cake- it was rich but not too chocolatey or too sweet- just right. I had high expectations for the raspberry tart but I found the raspberries to be very soft and tasteless. The filling in the tart, however, was tasty.
author: Magda M.

description:
This is a sweet little bakery, not the best in SF by far, but very decent. 

I had the grilled merguez pannini and it was really great. The lamb sausage was really tasty, there was plenty of cheese oozing out the side, and there was just the right amount of harissa.

The lady had their prosciutto cold sandwich which was incredibly uneventful. The bread was great, but the prosciutto was really boring (only flavor in it when we pulled it out of the sandwich was salt) and there wasn't that much cheese. So in the end this sandwich tasted like great bread, butter, and salt and that's about it. I guess the big bummer here was the lack of piggy goodness that one expects from a good prosciutto.

The salad was great though, with a slightly creamy balsamic dressing on some fresh greens--really nice complement to the sandwiches.

We also shared a pastry which was so-so.

The tea selection is really poor (just some boring bagged teas that you'd see at an inexpensive bagel/donut shop) and the coffee was mediocre.

The staff were very nice, attentive, and prompt. No complaints there.

I guess I'd come back here if I was really hungry for breakfast and in Chinatown, but that's about it.
author: Josh H.

description: I do not pretend to be some coffee snob with my pour over coffee filters and single-source coffee beans. But, I do enjoy a nice cup of coffee. After consuming my glorious chocolate donut from Happy Donuts (happily across the street) Bob and I decided getting a nice coffee would be just the ticket. We don't ever really go out for coffee, we stick to our basic coffee at home so when we go out for coffee - it better be worth it! Bob ordered a latte and I had the cafe creme. Oh my dear coffee bean! This was the best coffee drink I have ever had! I am pretty sure the cafe creme is espresso with steamed half-and-half, so really, how could it be bad? But, it was glorious! Rich and creamy, not too sweet and not bitter at all. Bob's latte was unbelievable. It was perfect in every sense of the word! I am used to the watered down fake tasting versions you get at Starbucks, but this was something else. It was just really REALLY good. I do have to say that I am a little bummed that I do not live here. The idea of grabbing a donut and a delicious coffee from Brioche Bakery sounds like a pretty amazing way to start any morning!
author: Keshar N.

description: We came looking for a Sunday brunch, and found it here.  We both had the eggs benedict - francaise style - accompanied with roasted potatoes and fresh fruit, and it was very good.  Great coffee, too, plus reasonably priced.  And there is sidewalk seating, for those willing to brave the cacophony along Columbus Street.
author: Rick B.

description: Had brunch here today! I found this little gem through a Gilt City deal. You order at the counter and they give you a number. We ordered the Avocado scramble and the eggs Benedict. We also got two pastries and coffee. Everything we had was very tasty...especially the pastries. I appreciated that the brunch items come with fruit as well and we both felt very full after the meal but not super heavy. The owner was very friendly and came by to ensure we enjoyed our meal. The only thing i would change is they did not have jelly available for the toast they provided with the scramble, which we found a bit odd. Other than that great food and nice location.
author: Nicole S.

description: Absolutly fabulous... Long time I have not had something so good and enjoy my breakfast. There's this taste of france in everything they are selling... chocolate croissant, enormous almond croissant, the tarte are fresh and delicious, fresh orange juice, I leave in Miami and it really worth it to do round trip to eat their brioches... Or maybe they should deliver everything is At a really affordable price...
author: Gilles H.

description: The staff are wonderfully helpful and friendly, and the coffee and pastries are delicious. Stop by for a quick snack and people watch at one of their outdoor tables. The bus stops right in front and the people watching is great.
author: Mo A.

description:
I love Brioche and walk up the street from work when I'm treating myself to lunch and some Vitamin D...Their Nicoise sandwich and the salad are both excellent! Im pretty picky about how I like my tuna (hate too much mayo) but Brioche does it right every time! Their Grilled Chicken Salad is also great, not youre run of the mill chicken salad. The chicken is grilled with spices and has a bit of a tang to it, but the salad and veggies and the dressing help balance it all out. 

The service is always great, the owners, a husband and wife team, are extremely nice and welcoming and the shop its self is always clean and very cute! 

Très délicieux!!
author: Alissa C.

description:
I walk past this place every single day on my way to work, and always looks so tempting.  But it's either too early and not open yet, or I need to hustle to work, so no time to linger over a pastry and coffee.   Fortunately this morning I was finally able to visit this lovely mecca of baked goods - totally worth the wait!  

I had a plain brioche, which was gorgeous, buttery and sweet, and my partner had a plain croissant, also buttery delicious.  We shared a regular coffee, the mocha java flavor in a heavy white mug, and it was a really lovely way to start the day.  

Counter staff was pleasant and efficient, and seemed to know many of the customers who came in while we sat in the comfortable cafe seating.  Fun artwork of jellyfish on the walls to look at, if you get tired of people watching.
author: Jaimie M.

description: all you vegetarians out there (and carnivores too), come here and try their grilled veggie panini.  just do it.  you will thank me after the first bite.  i must note that the sandwich is not as "flavorful" aka salty as most are used to, but it allows all the different veggie flavors to shine.  the bread was soft, pesto was awesome, cheese was gooey, overall a solid piece of work.
author: Melissa Y.

description:
I went here last weekend and was very happy I did. I was walking up Kearny headed for North Beach and crossed Columbus and decided that this looked like a cool place to chill for a while.  

I had the best brioche here I've ever had in San Francisco. Nothing fancy...not the brioche with stuff  in it... just a plain brioche and it rocked---just the right texture that almost melted in my mouth with a wonderful old world flavor right out of the Left Bank somewhere.

I also had a single Americano which was served in a large mug and was strong and hot and not bitter. I sat a while and read my book while customers came and went and some stayed to savor their purchases and check out the North Beach scene from their window seat.

Besides the wonderful food I was also impressed by the people behind the counter, some of the nicest people you'll ever meet. Although this place has been getting good reviews for a while it is under new management as of a month or so ago. 

So if you've never been here or haven't been here lately definitely check it out.
author: Nivek M.

description:
Completely awful experience here. 

Ordered a lemon-poppy seed and blueberry muffin. Paid $5 (!!).

Gave the lemon-poppyseed to my girlfriend. She thought the muffin was from Costco. 

Took the blueberry muffin, smelled it. It smelled like an onion bagel. It also tasted like an onion bagel. 

I literally spit it out it was so bad. I will never go back to try anything else from this place.
author: Alex O.

description:
I haven't been to the store in SF; instead, I've been buying the baked goods from Brioche Cafe at the farmer's market, where they sell under the name "Crepe and Brioche."

Overall, the offerings tend to be a little too heavy on the oil and sugar for me, but it is at least in a good, all-natural way, and not a corn syrup-y, hydrogenated soy oil kind of way.   I'm a huge fan of the almond croissant because it is filled with a very generous amount of marzipan (most bakeries are stingy with their marzipan), and the whole wheat loaf covered in pumpkin seeds is absolutely awesome to tear apart with your hands when you're lazing about and needing a messy, crumb-producing snack.
author: James L.

description:
Top Notch!! I've been coming to Brioche for a couple years now and the food is very, very good! The staff rocks, the desserts are AWESOME, and the CHICKEN TARGINE is the BEST!!

Couldn't give a better recommendation...
author: Netdizzle F.

description:
This place has real brioche! Yeasty, buttery, the whole nine. But I must say that they don't always have them, I suspect other restaurants come in and clean them out.
The eggs benedict were one of the best versions I've ever eaten, runny eggs, beautiful cream sauce, terrific with my addition of Tabasco.
My companion had a croissant sandwich with chicken-apple sausage, cheddar, tomato, and egg. She loved it.
We'll be back.
author: monk f.

description: I came here for lunch on a weekend  trip to San Francisco. It was my favorite meal while I was there. I got the avacado BLT and it was amazing! I split the raspberry chocolate marquise for dessert and it was delicious! I would definitely go back
author: Cari C.

description:
I am a croissant afficiando and fiend.  And these are THE BEST I've had since Paris.  And I asked...the pastry chef was trained there, so thats why they're so freaking amaaaazing!  I buy the plain and ham and cheese croissant (which I somehow justify as better because it contains protein) when I walk to work and man, just amazing.  Haven't had anything else, not sure if I will because I try to limit myself to stopping by here only 2x a week....but its torture because I just want them delivered to my front door every day.

Oh and be sure to have them warm it up for you - even better!

Plus the people that work there are friendly!  But they only take cash.
author: Erika M.

description:
Goodness.  I have my heart set on getting pastry and coffee here on this beautifual Saturday in SF.  We slept in and got out a little after 11am, perfect time for brunch/lunch and The House was near empty...but we were focused.  I was so happy to see the red umbrella and seatings outside, that means they are open!

There were a few customers in front of us and a few inside.  The sun is out and the sky is blue, why not sit outside?  While I thought I was getting a brioche, something else caught my eyes.  The croquet monsieur ($6.50) ...2 thick slices of brioche with lots of cheese on top and loads of ham and cheese in between.  I just can't keep my eyes away from it so that's what we ordered - the guy said it will take 7 minutes, no hurry!  We got a cup of latte each and grabbed one of the 2 tables outside.  It was so nice to soak up the sun...the latte and sandwich were brought out to us.  The Croquet Monsieur is absolutely glorious!  The cheese melted on top and inside while the outside was crispy and soft inside.  The brioche was buttery and just melts in the mouth.  Every biteful was heaven.  

We also got a fruit fougasse ($2.50) - another delicious goodness.  We had planned to get dessert afterward but we were so full after sharing the croquet monsieur that we had no room.  We had our eyes on the sugar brioche and another brioche with custard filling...that just means we'll be returning soon.

Great service, great price, fantastic food...what more can one ask for?
author: Gloria H.

description:
I like to walk up and down all the bread/pastry vendors at the farmer's market,  multigrain levins, sticky buns, croisants.. all looking extremely tasty and amazing. But then something caught my eye.. anchovy fougasse? 

I'm very much a savory person and entire filets of anchovy in a bread is a MUST TRY. It was so incredibly doughy with all that salty fish goodness that I had to return the following week to get TWO! 

Looking forward to trying all the other delicious baked goods!
author: tessie n.

description: Brioche is right on top of my office so I am often here for lunch.  I love the tartine gourmande which is an open faced veggie sandwich.  The bread is yummy and there is a nice assortment of veggies on there.  I like that I have a place with healthy options close to me because if I didn't, I would be eating pasta and chinese food all day with my office being right between North Beach and Chinatown. I also get macarons here every morning for my clients of the day and they all love them (and so do I because I am also eating them throughout the day with them tsk tsk).  Bonus points because they also have wifi and almond milk.
author: Kim W.

description: I love this place. Found it on yelp while I was visiting the city for the day - and yes it made all my French bakery dreams come true. Croissants, brioche, tartes, bagettes, there was even gelato which made my boyfriend very happy. Excellent quality, super friendly staff, sweet spot. I'll be back.
author: Coco J.

description: Honestly, I was on my way to another pastry destination when my family and I stopped in here. When traveling with youngsters (two kids under the age of 5) it can be a bit difficult to find an accommodating place to sit and eat, stress free. Well, we found it. The food was absolutely fantastic (chocolate croissant and avocado scramble recommended) as was the coffee. Best part? Super quick, super friendly staff. AND, it was cheap. Or at least, below average for SFO.
author: Kris W.

description: Great little cafe with very tasty pastries. It's a nice place to go to people watch. The staff is friendly and the ingredients used are fresh. They have a large array of different breads. They also have a wide selection of salads. Recently they have been updating their menu so it may change from day to day. However, all new menu items I have tried have been quite good!
author: Elle V.

description:
just got a blueberry muffin for $2.50 and its horrendous.  it tastes like its from costco.  its freezing cold/not even room temperature and its not a muffin, its a cupcake (tastes like its soaked in butter and sugar syrup).  disgusting.

go to napa ranch instead.  the food there is meh, but the muffins are amazing.
author: Olivia T.

description: Great coffee, incredible pastries. Nice staff.  A bit pricy. Our favorite besides the Caffe Trieste around the corner.
author: Kermit T.

description: What a delightful cafe! The sandwiches are scrumptuous and the deserts divine. Furthermore, the proprietor is a sweetheart, and the Parisian - Moroccan flair is not to be overlooked. The space is cozy, sunny and pleasant.
author: Ben S.

description: LOVED this place! The almond pastry was crazy good. Probably the best espresso I've had in SF. Super nice staff, great location.
author: Amanda B.

description:
UPDATE 11.20.07 (Original rating of 4 stars now bumped up to 5!)

I got back from Paris 4 days ago and have been missing the freshly made baguettes and pain au chocolat (from Eric Kayser's!  YUM!) already...  And so my search began Monday with Seller's Market (not going back for their croissants...) and ended (???) today (Tuesday) with Brioche Bakery...

Knowing full well that it would be close to impossible to find anything comparable in the FiDi, I am VERY happy to say that Brioche Bakery's pain au chocolats are quite excellent (even though they are not as good as the ones that I had a Kayser's every morning, they will do just nicely!).  Nice and flaky but a *tad* (just a *tad*) bit greasy (the ones I had in Paris were NOT greasy at all - how do those French do it?!) nevertheless, they were just yummy.

Right now, I'm enjoying the pate sandwich.  YUM!

Garlic cheese bread, this time topped with a few sliced tomatoes, was as delicious as ever.

Next time, I promise to try their brioche...  

-------------------
First time visit today after noticing this bakery one day...  The guy was already packing stuff up for the day (closing early, I presume??) and was out of panini and anything else lunch-able.  So I ended up getting a super yummy, cheesy, garlicky bread thingie.  Warmed.  (Really, the ONLY way to go.)  I finished this delectable goodie even before I reached the office.  It was piping hot as I unwrapped it from it's foil.  The cheese was nicely gooey and the whole thing was garlicky enough without being stinky.  

I can't wait to make the hike back up to BB to check out the place when the cases are fully stocked.  I've already talked this place up to M and we're going next week.  I already know that I'm going to get the chocolate croissant and whatever else that catches my eye.
author: Christine T.

description:
I'm not going to lie and say I go in here a lot, because I'm rarely in the vicinity and sometimes you just don't want a pastry, you know? But this is not to say Brioche is not worthy of the every-morning visit. 
On the days I do stop in, I'm never disappointed. Their selection is somewhat limited to the more traditional bakery items (croissant, brioche, cinnamon buns, breads) but everything I've eaten there is delightful, fragrant, and delicious.  

Also, I've come dangerously close on several occasions to quitting my job and moving to Europe. Because when you're on the way to spend eight hours of sunlight at your corporate torture tower, and some happy folks are taking their sweet time laughing and talking over croissants and coffee at one of Brioche's cute little bistro tables by the window overlooking the Avenue, you think, "Who are these genius bastards who can sit in bakeries until 10:00am on Tuesdays??" And then you realize, there by the faux fireplace and the glass case full of pastry, that a lot of the world values this kind of time, and there are places where people don't get up before the sun to pickle their eyes in front of a computer all day. 

So, they have Equator coffees, and though I'm not usually a fan of the super-dark roast, theirs is sweet and smoky and not bitter. Kind of like the people who get to sit in Brioche until whenever they damn well please.
author: Megan W.

description: Got some treats for Grandpa, and some milk tea.   Crowded, no place to sit while wait a couple a minutes.
author: JoeJet J.

description: I'd like to start by thanking God for my Pastry Ninja skills. I had the good fortune (or sixth sense) to get to brioche at perfect time just after opening but right before the pastries were being place on the wall. Having the run of the place and my pick I went with a pan chocolate, a cinnamon twist thingy, and an almond croissant. All were great but the almond and cinnamon made the early trip well worth it. Flawless victory.
author: David P.

description:
Je suis de retour à Paris? 

After living in Paris for some time, I've often been asked what my favorite thing about France was. Without hesitation, I reply, cafe sitting and the bread, food, and wine that blesses the table.

This is the closest thing to a TRUE authentic French cafe/boulangerie that I have visited in San Francisco. Bread baskets filled with artisan bread, fine French pastries, delicious sandwiches, and exceptional coffee to accompany...after all, in France, coffee accompanies every meal!

La Boulange is great, but it is extremely commercialized (Americanized). Go visit Brioche on Columbus if you want to have a true French cafe/boulangerie experience.
author: Matt D.

description: I work close by and this is one of my best go-to place for sandwiches...and I am a picky eater so I always end up getting a specialty sandwich.....but they do it with a smile....and the net result is a very happy me. I like their menu - but. I always manage to want something slightly different :-)  I also love the selection of music they play and all the people who work there. it is just one of my happy places to go.
author: Drew S.

description:
Small, super friendly family run bakery, I stop by whenever I am up in North Beach to get my coffee beans.

The owner actually remembers me...perhaps it was because I once came in looking for a baguette (as part of my search for the best baguette in SF), was disappointed they didn't have any in the basket, but he got one for me from behind the counter.

Their baguette is fantastic! Fresh, nice crust, some center...  I also tried their excellent pain au chocolate (chocolate croissant), their cinnamon twists.  Yesterday I tried their turkey panini.  Oh so good!!

They also offer all sort of breads, which makes me want to eat sandwiches all day...and I don't even like bread (well except for baguettes).
author: Amy F.

description:
I have a new best friend-the brownie.

I saw you out of the corner of my eye while buying some delish danishes.  You sat there, very innocently, chopped into smaller sample bites with toothpicks, quietly whispering, "Pick me."  Just the right amount of sweet, richness & crunch walnut-y goodness. And at $3 a pop per tiny round cake, far cheaper than any therapy. Goes well with ice cream too.

Thank you from the bottom of a sweet tooth's heart,
J.
author: Jen L.

description:
-- revised review 8/21/07
OK, it's back to amazing quality again. I had a double-capp and chocolate brioche yesterday morning, and the brioches were flaky and slightly salty, which compliments so well with the little bits of chocolate. The staff seemed more together than usual, so I think there were some personnel changes, and it's all back in action. Only criticism isnt' really a criticism- there's an emphasis on pastries, and it's not a patisserie!

-- revised review 1/8/07
I went here this morning and am now feeling sick- because the almond croissant now has this whipping cream in it and that is bad for me (note, will not be for all people). I think it's changed ownership- there was no brioches! And I overheard another customer wonder why there was no bread! My au lait was actualy an americano with milk, and I wish they told me they didn't have coffee. So I'm disappointed. I may visit again to give a definitive review, but it's sad. I was a big fan of this place.

-- earlier review
This is the best bakery in SF, bar none. Its brioches are fabulous. I have never been disappointed with the breads, either. I think a French tour bus unloads here, because every time I'm here it's all French all the time. The chocolate brioche is fabulous. I usually have a hard time leaving here, and usually buy a supply for a few hours down the road. It's not good for the waistline, but fabulous.
author: Anna B.

description:
NB: I have a weakness for cutesy street cafes.

On my first walk north-ward bound on Columbus, I was starving and telling myself "This time, yes, indeed, this time I will eat at a North Beach Italian restaurant" -- and lo-and-behold: my olfactory nerves get a whiff of fresh bread.  -END QUEST-.

** A fresh veggie (tomatoes, avocado, sprouts/ greens, aioli spread) pannini and a sparkling cider: $8.65 or so.

** I got in at 11:20 or so, and even by the time my lunch hour ended (12:10-ish) it wasn't jam-packed with a lunch hour crowd, which is always a plus.  

** The pastries & buns & breads looked dee-lish, and I cannot wait to try them some day.

** The staff was very pleasant

I sat in a corner, read a little, people watched a little, day dreamed (day dreamt?) a little, and ate to my appetite's content.

Yay! - For a lunch well had.
author: Anjali V.

description:
Not that I'm an expert on Italian bread this place has absolutely the best ciabatta I've ever had. I'm addicted to it. This bakery is on my way to work in the morning and if you get the freshly baked ciabatta, it just melts in your mouth. The crust is crispy but not hard. The interior moist and soft.

Warning: don't microwave the ciabatta. It loses it's fluff and collapses.
author: saurabh S.

description: A very lovely & delicious French cafe with blue awning on Columbus & Kearny. The staff is kind and going there is an intimate experience. Frankly, I would choose it any day over most of the Italian bakeries in North Beach, unless I wanted a cannoli. Pastries, cakes, macarons, gelato, baguette sandwiches & salads, and some brunch-y choices as well, like scrambles. Indoor & sidewalk seating. Very fair prices for the quality!!
author: Shannon R.

description:
Brioche is the bees knees!

They have an amazingly yummy selection of baked goods here! I happen to really like the almond croissant. It's flaky and gooey, sweet and perfect, light and heavy at the same time. But, really, everything is excellent. 

This is a great place to stop for a quick breakfast treat and a coffee drink in the morning. That seems to be Brioche's busiest time. But, it's also worth a lunchtime or late afternoon trip. They make good sandwiches here. 

Brioche is small, but there always seems to be room, whether you're there to study, meet a friend or just getting something to go. 

Brioche is cash only. The pastries are a little pricey but worth every penny.
author: Sarah R.

description: Stopped in about 10:30 to check out this bakery/cafe after reading the reviews on Yelp. I was not disappointed. Had the Croque Monsieur Panini on house made brioche. Hot, crispy, mouthwatering. I ate every last bite and a few of the crumbs that fell on my shirt. This place is a little gem. Friendly guy behind the counter took my order. I will definitely go back to try some of the other offerings. It all looked great.
author: Richard F.

description:
So I really want to take off one star because they close so early (230pm) - and they dont take credit cards- but how can I hate on this perfect little coffee shop (slash bakery)?

I have soy lattes almost every day and they make the most amazing foam. I have yet to eat an entire baked goody- but based on their samples, they are ONE BILLION times better then starbucks. . .
author: Alicia V.

description:
My wife and I had just worked out at the College of San Mateo.  While we were leaving our eyes were drawn to this line of 25 people long who were standing in the freezing cold for what turned out to be Brioche Bakery at San Mateo's Farmer's Market.   This pasterrie is the real deal, French bakers, some of whom have thick French accents.  I asked the server what was a certain yellow flower shaped pastry.  He kept saying "lemon chicken, lemon chicken"  I still don't know what it is.  

Anyhow, we ordered the rasberry tart, apple tart, apple cinnamon muffin, raisin hazelnut bread, and brioche, all for $23.  The muffin was the best out of the bunch.  It was moist from top to bottom.  My wife loved the brioche and apple tart.  SM's Farmer's Market is a great place, and this bakery definitely is worth the trip.
author: Rhinocort D.

description: Had the pleasure of spending a couple hours here enjoying free wifi, tasty lunch, great coffee, and watching the world go by.  A piece of France in North Beach!  Beet salad with toasted bread was tasty...super fresh ingredients and plenty filling.
author: Dave S.

description:
Ok, five stars this place does get, for a few simple reasons

1. Delicious organic SF Coffee Co. coffee that's always fresh and never, EVER burnt.

2. The day-old bag o' breads. One of these days I'll be able to pick up the freshies at $2 a pop, but for now myself and the rest of the broke-ass community will gleefully pick up bags of muffins, garlic and cheese loaves and what have you for $4 (or $3 for four mutha-fuffin muffins, muffa!).

I would buy a sandwich but I'm a brokeass, so I have to assume that they're good (they look good). Also, Nate from Cape Cod (he's got the real-life 'V For Vendetta' look going on, spot-on facial hair though he's got to work on the eerie grin) makes a "killer cole slaw" that's "actually lethal." Someone put a stop to him.
author: Chris R.

description:
This place is my little slice of heaven during the work week. 

To say this place serves up great sandwiches is an understatement. This place serves up the best sandwiches I've ever had! Quality ingredients, crazy delicious bread, and a chipotle sauce that I believe is the secret 'ingredient' in making these delicious sammys. 

The pastries are also very fresh and there is a whole slew of goodies to choose from! From croissants, to tarts, to mousse, etc.. The wonderful aromas hit you as soon as you walk in the cafe.

The owner is really cool and the service is very friendly. 

Really recommend to anyone who likes good sandwiches, perfect cappuccinos, and a leisure/relaxing environment. This place also boasts a killer view of the Transamerica building.
author: nina B.

description:
I got a bad feeling here.  Plus the cinnamon shaker dumped a load of cinnamon on  my cappucino, ruining it.  What up with that?  Get a decent cinnamon shaker please.  I can't be the only one that happens to.

The baked goods were OK though.
author: Rose Q.

description:
Really cute, European-style bakery; with really cute, charming European servers.  I love the tiny counter, beveled baked goods display, charming Bentwood chairs, sunny dining area, tiled flooring, large windows facing Columbus and even the faux fireplace (cute).  Ideal place for a quiet, leisurely conversation.

Good selection of baked goods, including, of course, several types of brioches; savories; breads. Decent Americano, tho I prefer the one at SBUX.  Yes SBUX.

Minus one star because there was that one time when I came here just to browse (because I have a pornographic addiction to baked goods), and the guy manning the counter was neither charming nor friendly.  But yeah, still cute.  Darn the Euros.
author: Natasha S.

description:
Absolutely the best almond croissant I ever had in my entire life!  They sell out almond croissants before 2pm almost everytime I visit now.  

Today, I was lucky enough to grab the last three (one for the bf, one for the roomie, and one for me!) And I told the cashier that they have the best almond croissant ever and they said they make them the traditional way.

Ohh...  I tried so many almond croissant place, and I keep coming back to this one!
author: Gigi T.

description: Simply amazing :) Hands down some of the most savery tastin treats you will find in da east bay. Only bad part you relly have to try not to come here too much..
author: Ron W.

description:
This is for their stand at the Castro Farmer's mkt. I've been to the retail cafe, but they have almost none of the great stuff from the market, so I've not gotten anything there.

Oh Brioche, you are the reason I walk 5 miles RT to the Castro Farmer's mkt. I LOVE YOU!  I love your cheese toasts (though I no longer eat them, read on if you'd like to know why...), the pretzels,  the olive bread, the surprise stuff that appears and I don't know what it is but I want it, the cinnamon twists, the chocolate scone things...I have not had one thing I did not like.  Most of what I've had, I love.  It's a problem.  Oftentimes I buy one thing, eat it while buying produce, and go back and buy another before I leave the market. And it's gone within blocks. Damn.

About those cheese toasts- I used to rush there to get one before they sold out. But no longer. Why? Well, one, I always got heartburn and queasy after eating it.  And two, I decided to ask one day (jokingly) which was healthier- the toast or a ham and cheese croissant.  The guy said the croissant. I asked why, and he seemed hesitant to tell me. I persisted. That cheese toast, which I obviously knew was greasy, had WAY more fat than even I suspected. If you've had one, you know how oily they are. Well, apparently before they melt that crapload of tasty cheese on top, they brush the bread very liberally with mayonnaise, or rather aioli (what's the difference?).  That would explain the heavy feeling I got after eating it, and the heartburn.  Well, I've had to let that one go. But there's plenty of other amazingly tasty treats to buy. Too many.  

I took my BFF there when she came to visit and she got some thing that was basically flaky/puff pastry (like croissant) layered with butter and sugar. It was like eating a butter pie. No, that's not right, it was like eating a really dense, sweet, buttery cloud. Holy crap. Obscene. Obscenely good, that is. 

I wish they'd carry some of those fancy treats at the cafe, which is only a 20 minute walk from me. But I should be grateful that they don't.
author: Allucaneat G.

description:
Blackforest Ham on toasted bread with Chipotli Mayo, & tomato= Winner for me.
-1 star because it  takes awhile for there toaster to heat up :),
author: john c.

description:
I got the almond croissant and it was delicious. It was light, flaky, not overly sweet, and had a wonderful amount of almond filling. The almonds were also perfectly toasted. 

Very nice and friendly staff. The cafe is relaxing and comfortable. I liked the paintings in the bathroom but it made me upset that someone would cut one of them. 

I'll have to come back to try the broiches.
author: Linda S.

description: One of the best cappuccinos we have ever had in our lives! The baguettes were so fresh with crusty outsides and warm moist insides! I had the nicoise sandwich and it was so so so so good! Definitely going back!
author: Enid F.

description:
Predicament this morning:

I walk up to my office on Pacific Ave and pull the door. It's locked. It's 9:30.  I am the first person here (I am never the first person here) and I do not have keys nor the alarm code.

"Hrm..." I think. "Where can I go to waste 15 minutes until other people will assuredly show up?"

Now I can go to the starbucks at the corner of Pacific and Battery, but I remembered that having a line out the door as I was walking up from bart. So I decided to take a walk up Columbus and see what wonderful little shops there were (the restaurants I always see on my way to Wells Fargo when I go during my lunch hour).

So I stop at the Brioche Bakery because it's been quite a while since I had good brioche, and I remember seeing it quite often. The smell was fantastic and everything looked so good. Of course, I have a soft spot in my heart for quaint little bistros, so i had to stop inside and give them a try.

I only had a nonfat cappuccino and a plain brioche, but both were very good. The cappuccino was not the best I've had, but decent and they obliged my request for low foam. That alone makes them better than most coffee shops.  The brioche was light, soft, buttery and not too sweet (but not overly greasy like many places). More than that, their pastry cabinet looked excellent and was full of wonderful, delicious looking things like almond croissants and various quiches. (Upon reading yelp reviews, I will have to go back for the almond croissant sometime).

Great little shop with reasonable prices and one of the best brioches I've ever had. Service was inviting and friendly, yet they don't take credit cards and I had to dig for change at the bottom of my purse. Best of all, they took up just enough time where I got breakfast and made it to the office just as everyone else was arriving.

Great, highly recommended way to start the morning.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Hands down the BEST brioche in the Bay Area. 

Their cinnamon buns are out of this world. Crusty and sweet exterior with hints of cinnamon, but wait til you get to the middle. Wow, it's just really really good. Soft, melt-in-your-mouth center covered with nuts and cinnamon-sugar. I'm an Arizmendi's fan but for cinnamon buns, I would get them here any day. Not that the former is bad, they have decent buns too, but the cinnamon buns at Brioche bakery is the best I've had. There are no words to describe it. 

Another favorite of mine is their chocolate croissant. Perfectly flaky crust with dark bittersweet chocolate inside. Heat it up to melt the chocolate and you're in croissant heaven. 

A must-stop if you're in the area!

get the cinnamon buns, get the cinnamon buns, GET the CINNAMON BUNS!
author: Erika I.

description:
Popped in here for the first time today after walking by many times. Everything looks delicious and I've lived in Paris so that's a good sign. I didn't try to croissant today, but next time for sure.

I wanted to pick up a quick lunch after a yoga class across the street and the chicken wrap caught my eye. I asked about that and the special of the day, kebab with couscous and since the latter took 10 minutes, I decided to go with the wrap. It was massive and they guy described it as having chicken, homemade hummus, a cilantro yogurt sauce, cucumber salad and cheese. I thought I'd give it a try and it was absolutely delicious.

While it was big and definitely filling, all the ingredients seemed really fresh and healthy. I thought it was good value for $7.75 too.

It takes a lot to get 5-stars, so I need to go back a few more times and try out their other stuff, but so far, so good!
author: Lauren M.

description:
FIRST YELP REVIEW!!! yay.

Okay, so i usually don't wake up before 830 every/any morning on any day of the year. This morning was most definetly an exception since my friend "TRACY"  invited me to have breakfast with her at the BROICHE CAFE.. 

Well anyways, I can't imagine myself, personally, to be cheery and able to take customers' requests that early in the day. The employees at this cafe is overtly friendly which set the mood for the rest of my day. THANKS! I ordered a Double Soy Latte with Vanilla Syrup.. yes they don't have Vanilla soy, which is honestly, really lame considering all cafes in san francisco carry vanilla soy...*deduct one star* I also ordered a Ham and Cheese Croissant which was extremely tasty, it wasn't too salty like Peet's Crossant or too cheesy.

Overall, the food was great, service was perfect and the lack of vanilla soy was dissapointing. Despite the minor flaw I would HIGHLY RECOMMEND this cafe!

P.S.  .. Limited Seating and CASH ONLY please.
author: Alex C.

description: We make it a practice to visit Brioche every time we're in the Financial District. The fresh coffee selection, filling quiche, fruit topped tarts, and al fresco experience are something not to be missed. It's only a short walk to Brioche from the major hotels in the FD.
author: Matthew K.

description: On special mornings, when the free coffee they serve at my office just won't cut it, I treat myself to a small latte and sometimes even a pastry at Brioche Bakery & Cafe. This cafe serves the most consistently amazing lattes.  Drinking it makes me feel warm and fuzzy inside. These are the only lattes I've had in S.F. where I didn't have to add sugar or some of those blue packets to take the bitterness out. It's prepared perfectly, no need to add anything!  I've had the raspberry almond muffin and a few other cheese pastries and are equally as delicious.
author: Libby A.

description:
I appreciate that they're open at real bakery hours - none of this "opening at 10 or 11" business. However, I was surprised to find the selection to be fairly limited at 9:45 on a Saturday morning. If they had already sold out of a lot of things by that time, good for them, although maybe they should bake more. Anyway, I actually didn't feel all that tempted to have anything, which is unheard of for me at a bakery (and everything looked fine... but nothing stood out, really), until I saw the chocolate brioche and another concoction adjacent to it. I couldn't tell what it was, so I asked, and the guy said it was a morning bun. I thought those normally had citrus zest (although a quick google shows this is not necessarily the case), and anyway, this one didn't. Instead, it had a pleasantly rich dough and lots and lots of cinnamon and sugar (for the first time, more than I wanted - there was actually about an eighth of an inch disc on the bottom that was near inedible). 

The morning bun was probably a 4, but it was $2.50, and the overall selection didn't seem so great. On the other hand, the employee was nice while I was being indecisive, they have decent books around to read if you stay, and there's day old bread (not sure of the price). I'll go back and see if I just caught them at a weird time.
author: Lisa K.

description: Sadly, I was a bit disappointed. I may be tainted as I just got back from London and the croissants there can NOT be beaten. Decent, but not my favorite
author: Tacia C.

description:
I go here every day. Well, make that 5 days a week - I work across the street. Brioche is my go-to coffee place, because they have the best drip coffee within 2 blocks of my office. They probably have the best espresso drinks too, but I prefer drip. AND the drip is self-serve (it's in those canisters. You know what I mean, the kind that keep the coffee nice and hot but don't burn it).

I don't get pastries every day, but if I made my pastry-eating decisions based on deliciousness only, I would. Unfortunately, my pastry-eating decisions also involve budget and health (pastries are about $2 to $2.50, but it adds up). I highly recommend the plain croissants and cinnamon twists. My co-worker loves the sugar brioche. And my mom buys the whole-wheat raisin hazelnut bread at the Marin farmer's market every week, and LOVES it. Oh, and they also make great sandwiches. And brownies. And cookies, and cakes, and once I had the quiche and it was delicious. . . you can see why this is a 5-star review. Clearly, Brioche = the win.
author: zoe s.

description:
I really like this place!

Their coffee is good and their staff are friendly. It makes me happy.

I am a huge fan of fluffy bread, and their fluffy sandwich rolls are absolutely to die for. Mmmmmm. I just eat them plain, they are THAT good. Or dipped in coffee. I don't know if that's weird, but I've been doing that for years and it is delicious. So, Brioche sandwich roll + Brioche coffee = highlight of my morning.

I am happy that this little gem of a cafe exists in North Beach, amid all the mediocre cafes. I just wish they were open at night too.
author: -kiko- S.

description: This place has evolved over the year: few more things on the menu and now has some sidewalk seating, the latter being a nice addition. Latte was delicious but the fruit tart was below avg. The crust was too starchy and you needed a drill to cut through it. Owner/managers are very nice. Throw in some soft accordion Italian music in the background are we're good, Brioche.
author: Tripp S.

description: Come here every day for an iced coffee. Yum. I have tried almost everything here and have always been happy. Love the staff, love the music, love the outside seating.
author: E S.

description:
I removed one star cause they removed the outlets to power my laptop and it is harder for me to work from there now. I still love that place. I might have to get a new laptop battery if I want to keep enjoying their AMAZING pastries. 
Keep on the good job Brioche !
author: Fred M.

description:
Update: it's been over a year since I initially reviewed this place and despite some turn-over in the staff, the quality continues to amaze me. I no longer step in just for coffee as their lunches now have me in awe: today's special was lamb & split pea soup which was substantial enough for a good appetite and simply delicious. Also: try their bread pudding (heated & with whipped cream) -- to die for! The people there are fantastic and patiently cater even to finicky customers with grace.

I walk blocks and pass up not one, not two, but three "high class" coffee establishments every day just to get the best cappuccino in town. What's so special? Admittedly, i'm not the best coffee connoisseur but I know, and they know, that a cappuccino needs foam and lots of it! That, and my coffee critic friend swears by their beans too. Plus they bake quality bread. Yes, i'm European (snort!) and I'm spoiled, and the nice folks at Brioche sure do their part to keep it that way! Thanks!
author: Nicola G.

description:
The cutest little cafe! I've been to a lot of places which have better pastries but the ambiance and service are worth it. They have the best (and one of only few places at all) chicken pot pie ever! My  favorite!
Coffee and pastries good, just come daly for the pastries, sandwiches are fantastic, prices are reasonable, and the fact that it's a husband and wife team, makes it worth it. One of the few caves in north beach that are worth it!
author: Daph C.

description: Best chai latte ever. The food is delicious as well. Would recommend to anyone. It isn't super cheap but definitely worth it. Friendly staff, very clean place.
author: Elizabeth A.

description: Excellent pastries. These alone are enough draw. The crispy, chewy, flaky pastry is filled with plenty of fruit and cream for me. It's so hard to find excellent pastries but with Brioche it's a cinch.
author: Michael H.

description: Nice little cafe. My croissant  was great and the  cappuccino was perfect.
author: T G.

description:
Deelicious! 

While searching Yelp for some help on a new groove for sweets for office meetings, I stumbled across Brioche. "Sounds good" I thought, so I rounded up my cohorts and trudged everybody up the hill to try out some delectables for lunch. The BIG hit was the chicken pot pie - just like your grandmere would make if'n you was french. My salami sandwich and orzo salad were delightful (though too much to eat in one sitting - the sandwich was really big). And we got a few sweet treats to share and review.

The chocolate chip cookie was deemed "fine, though nothing special" which is ok, since it's a french bakery and they really should be excelling at things with FAR more butter in them!!  ;o)

The raspberry tartlet was really good with a slightly crispyish shell and beautifully deflated whole raspberries nestled amongst the jam base.

But everyone's fave, hands down, was the chocolate lava cake. Gooey and rich, it was served in a small container and was truly transporting. A lovely, dark mass of sinfully delicious chocolate. Thankfully I only had a bite, otherwise I think I'd be in a food coma right now!

Definitely will become part of the regular lunch rotation. I mean really...who doesn't like to feel transported to a small cafe in Paris for a few minutes of their busy work day??? (Several small tables inside and on the sidewalk if you choose to extend said mental vacation for a bit, rather than trudging back to your office!)
author: Elizabeth E.

description: I'm going to still keep this 4 stars because my chocolate croissant was so good (even at a steep $2.50), but I wanted a Brioche at 8:00 yesterday and they didn't have any!  That's like going to Hooter's and having them tell you that all the large-breasted women are out sick.  I think if this is consistent, I might lower them because you can't have your premier product in the name of your business and then not have any.
author: Marc S.

description: 3.5 nice and fresh. be prepared though for a large almond croissant (non powdered) with a nice moist filling and very sweet.  hard to finish.
author: Rob C.

description: Best bakery near financial district. Love the paninis here. The vegetable one is very good and so are the salads, especially the nicoise salad.
author: Julie Z.

description:
You know the feeling when you try a new coffee for the first time and you feel it?

The opposite of drinking your 8th coffee from the office pantry and not being able to tell the difference.  I walk by on my way to work (east side on the way to work for the coffee and west side on the way home for a drink at Bing's!).  

Never heard of Brioche before but brought some to the office (one of each?) where it was well received.  Once they also gave me samples to pass around to see if we wanted to use them for catering.   Only funny thing is that it seems like someone new is always working behind the counter (though they are always very friendly!).
author: Songbae L.

description:
I had a breakfast sandwich that came with a salad.  The salad was fantastic - a nice tart/vinegary dressing with very robust greens.  I thoroughly enjoyed the salad and would go back just for that!  The sandwich was also pretty good, and all in all, found it to be a pretty satisfying breakfast.

There's not a lot of seating, but the ambiance is still pretty nice.
author: Thomas S.

description:
This place is my go-to for a tasty snack and it's about 40 feet from work. All the staff are nice, my dog Hudson gets to come in with me and wait for cappuccinos and  it's not expensive.

Yay Brioche!
author: Sallyanne E.

description: Excellent pastries, very good sandwiches, and even true French baguette! What else?!
author: Bruno P.

description:
Ahh... The existential hubris that is the baked good... Notice "good" in the name, in spite of our Puritanical focus on "health" and "calories"... Somehow our etymological forebearers knew that flour, butter, sugar hold a significant place in our private pantheons to ward away the solipsistic abyss that thinking people entertain... Enter the Almond Croissant! Plato could not have imagined a better example for his quaint notion of the ideal object than this modest item. It IS the model almond croissant. I shall eat any other almond croissants with the memory of this one; This one is the ideal, the perfection of the almond croissant. 

They have bread, also. It is good, but does not inspire me. I buy from them at the Farmer's Market (where else?), but the Cafe on Columbus is a cute little cave ; ).
author: Alex C.

description:
Waouh, I went to Brioche Bakery this morning and got the best chocolate croissant I've had over the last 10 years at least. Trust me, I know what I'm talking about - I'm frog, a real one. Born and raised in the South of France, I lived in Paris for many years and even in my homeland, it's been harder and harder to find good croissants. Bakers often use frozen dough, which ends up giving over-flaky crust. They also put too much chocolate in there and the chocolate is too sweet, not "cocoa-y" enough.
None of these at Brioche Bakery. My chocolate croissant reminded me of the ones my Dad would buy every Saturday morning on the way to school to help me cope with the fact that, yeah, I was going to school 6 days a week! 
Thanks, Brioche Bakery. I'll be back very soon.
author: Cherinoute S.

description: I love this place. I come here at least a few times a week for lunch. All of the sandwiches are so good! The quality of the ingredients are superb. Their beet salad and daily soups are some of my favorites. I usually end up taking a loaf of fresh bread as well.
author: Ariana B.

description: Excellent pastries and coffee. I spend quit a bit of time here since my office is around the corner and appreciate having the close escape.
author: Paul N.

description: Not bad, but not great either. Had the quiche, prosciutto tartine and the broccoli soup. Everything was a bit under salted, but the bread was fairly good. The coffees we had were okay (latte and cappuccino), with better than expected foam.
author: Solomon B.

description: This is as good as it gets people! This is my go to place on the weekends. There french toast and croissants are out of this world! The chef, Etston always personalizes each dish where can you get that anywhere else? you can't! I'm telling you once you try this place out you''ll never stop coming!!!!! So come on down to Brioche.
author: Vanessa L.

description: Good but kinda pricey.  I like the Farmer's Market version better.
author: Matthew P.

description: This place is awesome. I live a couple of blocks away and came here once for brunch. Haven't stopped coming here since. Everything I've had is really good and the staff is very friendly. They also have Free WiFi.
author: Mikhail C.

description: The pastries here are the best we've found so far, but still not the same as what you can find in the best bakeries. Still a very good value and a nice place to stop if you are in the neighborhood. The service is fast and friendly and the prices are good.
author: Sandy L.

description: I love this place! its great for breakfast and quick lunches. Their bread is great and everyone is really nice. I want to go their for brunch soon, the brunch looks really good!!
author: Elyse M.

description: I became acquainted with brioche bakery at a farmers market and loved the Bostok- French toast with almond paste. I stopped by today after a fully clothed meal at naked lunch. I got the blueberry financier. It wasn't memorable a bit dry and not enough almond flavor.
author: Monica L.

description:
this cute little bakery and coffee stop is en route to my office, so i often get off the 9BX, yogi in bag, and hop right into Brioche Bakery for a fresh almond croissant (THE BEST) or a cinnamon morning bun or brioche, and either some free trade/organic coffee or tea.  their baked goods and breads are baked fresh, are delicious, and beat the pants off of anything you could get at those chain coffee shops.  and you kinda feel like your in Paris!

they always have baskets full off day olds that are still soft and gushy like they were just baked!  often times i get their bread and make what i don't use into yummy croutons or french toast.  

they have seating out front and get the morning sun, as well as a few sunny spots inside, free wifi, and really nice folks working there.  i am not a starbucks fan AT ALL so i seek out places like this, and like to support neighborhood local business, so if you do too, this is a place to try.  yah, trieste makes a good cup'a'joe, but there's always a line, often no place to sit, and their pastries not so good...
author: Suzanne A.

description:
Had lunch here yesterday while I was wandering around with my dog. I had an open face sandwich with sliced apples, warm goat cheese and honey. It was delicious. It came with a nice salad, although the dressing was a bit too sweet and didn't contrast with the sweetness of the sandwich.

I got some bread and pastries to take home and they were ok. Not Tartine quality but worth eating. And at $8.50 it was a bargain compared to other lunches on Columbus. I'll be back!

The people here were REALLY nice to me and my hound. Really nice.
author: Scott H.

description: I'm pretty excited now that Brioche is open until 8:30pm!  That means I can walk past it after work and actually indulge in their delightful goodies.  No more heart-sinking dejection over seeing a CLOSED sign.  When I learned that the bakery is now under new ownership, I was concerned about their menu or quality of service possibly changing over time.  However, I came in yesterday for an almond croissant and a loaf of cheddar jalapeno bread, and they were still OUT OF THIS WORLD, and the new owners are a very sweet couple.  Glad I can keep my worries curbed for now.
author: Andrea U.

description:
I love this place! I get pastries for my office here all the time, and they're by far the best baked goods around. If they don't all get eaten at the office (rarely) I bring them home and my roommates always say, "holy __ ! what is this? It's amazing!" 
Every one of the staff has been kind and accommodating. They often make extra granola bowls for me when they run out. We just tried lunch there and it's proven to be quite yummy too!
author: J L.

description: I live in the neighborhood and am so happy to have this French-Moroccan cafe nearby.  The food is top-notch (try the chicken b'stilla!) and they have the best bread i've found in town.  They tend to sell out of the best pastries early, though.  The folks that run it couldn't be nicer, even when the tourists occasionally overwhelm the place.
author: Dean V.

description:
love at first sight...confirmed upon first sip of my super-foamy, perfect temperature, strong cappuccino and upon my first bite of a deliciously super flakey, fresh, perfectly sweet almond croissant. 

i stumbled upon this place while seeking out a new place to replace cafe trieste. don't get me wrong...that place is ok, but i needed a change of scenery to do some office work...got tired of the same ol' same ol' 'regulars' and the crazy ol' school jukebox. 

brioche bakery has a great all around european vibe. free wifi, small with cozy seating, super delicious pastries (which i will try all of eventually), organic free-trade coffee....plus a nice big window and a few tables outside for people watching your day away. 

whoops... i'd better get back to work!
author: Isabel C.

description: Nice place and good Atmosphere. Tried their Brioche and taste like a croissant but better.
author: Toeknee T.

description: Delicious grilled ham and cheese on brioche. The almond pastry filled with cream is also nice. A little dry
author: Christopher L.

description: LOVE this place!  The sugar brioche was custard like, just delicious!
author: Debbie T.

description:
I have been a customer of Brioche Bakery since it opened a few years ago and it just keeps getting better.

They make a very tasty and smooth espresso and my favorite treasure in the bakery is their olive fougasse (sp?), basically it is an oversized soft pretzel looking thing with a generous portion of black olives embedded in the dough.

The other pleasant surprise is the selection of lunch treats such as freshly made sandwiches and salads. What can I say except there is nothing that I have tried from Brioche that I have not been happy with. 

The atmosphere, considering the place has less than five small tables, is charming and the staff is always friendly. I love it when they have French popular music from the sixties playing in the background too.

I only hope they don't become to popular for me to get into and out of easily. Let's keep this place a secret, shall we?
author: David W.

description: I am not a believer about bashing business or being over expressive, but after the horrid experience i had at the brioche bakery on Wednesday, I feel that the right thing to do is to share my experience. I have been frequenting the bakery  for about a month now and think they have great food,attentive staff and great coffee but a HORRIBLE OWNER! I am not sure whether he noticed i had not gone yet and  was waiting  a while for my to go order but i heard cute a co motion coming from inside. upon further investigation i saw the owner be little, yell and completely disrespect one of the workers. It was one of the most awful things ive ever seen in my life! She looked terrified. I wanted to yell at him hey jerk lay off and pick on someone your own size! If this is how they run their business i will not be returning.
author: jamie lynn s.

description: Brioche is the only bakery I know that is closed on Sundays, but since they are the only good bakery available on Mondays, they definitely deserves 5 stars! best chocolate brioche in the bay area...
author: HRH S.

description:
*edited 2/27: I went back to Brioche on a whim, hoping they'd have the below-mentioned fruit and custard danish things. They did, and I got an apricot one. It was really quite good, with a crispy pastry edge, lots of apricot, and an almond-y custard filling. The girl was rude-ish again, although she again seemed nice to the person in front of me. Two and a half stars for one good snack, one bad one; mediocre rating maintained by snotty service on weekday mornings.*

I went here this morning after much anticipation. When I got to Brioche around 7:40am, I noticed that the dude in front of me was a regular, as the counter girl recognized him and was accommodating, offering to heat his order. That made me happy and expectant that my experience would be equally friendly. Not the case. I asked if there was any jam (I wasn't going to order a plain brioche without it) and she looked exasperated about having to check (which required that she look over her shoulder) and gave a curt "yeah". I then asked for a brioche to eat there and a single espresso (which was spelled 'expresso' on the wall, and pronounced the same by the girl). My espresso request also garnered exasperation and diverted eye contact. I told her she could get the drink after helping the only lady in line, but she ignored me and proceeded to make the shot and then bark "HERE is your exPRESSo". Whatevs.   
I sat down to eat and was pretty disappointed in the brioche: it was dry and crumbly and cold, not chewy and moist like I wanted. I don't eat that much brioche, but I think it's supposed to have the latter qualities, yes? I ate the round top and, while I knew I was pushing my luck, I asked the girl (who was doing nothing) if she wouldn't mind "sticking the rest in the oven for a minute", like she'd done for the dude who'd ordered before I did. "Sure." 
She brought it back literally 30 seconds later so that the top of it was barely warmed. 
 
I might go back here and revise my rating, but only because there were these danish-y looking things that involved mixed fresh fruit over custard in a pastry shell ...and I love both custard and fruit. I should have ordered that, but it only seemed right to first judge the place based on its namesake. 
The girl was borderline rude, but I'll tell myself that she's much better qualified than slinging pastries lets her express(o)....
author: Aimee F.

description: In addition to an excellent range of French breads adn pastries, I  love Chef Naima's Moroccan specialties --particularly the Chicken or Vegetable Bastilla and the daily Cous Cous.  You can't go wrong at this friendly and delicious spot!
author: Carol G.

description: If you want to impress your pals at the office, show up with a box of Brioche for your next morning meeting. People will flip! Order 3 of everything, it beats the socks off any sad old pastry from Starbuck's.
author: melissa n.

description: Came here today for breakfast before our Alcatraz tour.  Everything we had was wonderful (French toast, Avocado omelet, eggs benedict, fruit salad).  Hope to return soon.
author: Ann G.

description: The best (I guess probably only) flax seed bread you likely to find anywhere.  All the breads are actually great and the pastries are great as well.  The prices do reflect the quality, but many single serving items are large enough to be split between to people.  We buy everything from the Burlingame and San Mateo farmer's markets, which they attend regularly.
author: Kim M.

description: This place is a godsend because not only do they have tasty pastries, they have good coffee for cheap... and it's only 43 steps from my office. If it weren't for this place, i'd be stuck going to happy donuts for coffee... or *gasp*... making my own.
author: Bernie L.

description: They have some tasty treats here! Bread pudding to die for, delicate, flaky, buttery croissants, and fruit pastries to go nuts over! Their coffee is actually really yummy as well. Try it!!
author: Ericka A.

description:
i saw this place last night and thought "damm i haven't had a good brioche in a long time, time to get that fixed..."

and i'm still waiting to get a good brioche.

2 bucks for a plain brioche?!? Normally i would be more than willing to shell out the moo-lah for brioche, lord knows it's worth its weight in butter and eggs, but $2 for a brioche that is dry and has NO, I repeat NO buttery flavor at all is sooo not worth it

1 star for service, 1 for cleanliness, .25 star for the brioche (i've had better)
author: Annie C.

description: I can see why they call themselves the Brioche Bakery. Once you've eaten brioche here, you'll never be able to order brioche from any other place.
author: unhei k.

description: Go here and eat something. This is a new little spot that is very much a find. - And a very welcome change from the ridiculous Tea place that had been in the same location previously. Almost everything at Brioche is great. The breads are excellent and the brioche is extraordinary. Really, they do an excellent job and the low keyed staff is very friendly. Avoid anything pizza-like on top of a brioche and you'll be in great shape. (They get too soggy). The coffee too is very good and the cafe au lait is bucket-sized, so be prepared to stay awhile.
author: Eric F.

description: If you're carb inclined, the baked goods are fantastic; they remind me of the bakery I frequented back in Germany. Their walnut brownie and a warm glass of milk will make most woes go away.
author: Laura S.

description: This place has awesome everything.  The bread really stands out though, and the lamb sausage sandwich is great for lunch.  In fact, all the sandwiches I have tried were delicious.  But the breakfast here is to die for, and these days is the main reason I go.  The french toast is ridiculous, made with brioche toast and amazing fruit drizzle.  Honestly I don't get down with french toast very often, but Brioche french toast is in a class of its own.  My brother had the eggs benny (also served on a tasty brioche muffin instead of your average nooks and crannys english style), and it was killer as well.  Eggs cooked perfectly, and great potatoes along side.  The staff is super friendly, particularly the lady who runs the place, and patient (everything looks so good it takes a while to choose). Last time I was here, I had a strawberry danish, and omg it brought tears to my eyes.  To top it all off, its less crowded than most other north beach coffee shops, so you can actually chill and get some reading done. Admittedly, this place is a bit more $ than your average bakery/coffee joint, but its worth it.
author: Sam C.

description: wow i love this place... the bread food and people are wonderful. Enough said, let your taste buds render you with simple truthful words as well
author: kimberly c.

description:
i love their pastries, I've stopped by here couple of times. 

however, i don't recommend their dripped coffee.
author: sarah m.

description:
we stop in here every time we're in san francisco.  why? the best danishes we've ever eaten.  tasty, perfectly baked.  i had one this time with blueberies, apricots, and something else all in the shape of a face.  almost hated to eat it, it was so beautiful.

also excellent cappucino and sandwiches.  friendly waitstaff and reasonably priced.

as perfect as can be.
author: joel r.

description: I've looked long and hard for the perfect croissant in San Francisco and this place fits the bill.  Crumbly delicate fresh fragrant, metls in your mouth, big flake mess at the end but worth it.  Great jam.  They also sell fantastic slices of sourdough bread with crusty cheese and garlic.
author: Jedidiah B.

description: i've been saving my review for this place until the day i actually had one of their many brioche buns, even though i had already had croissants, levains, and other assorted bakery goods from the brioche. well, today was the day i had a brioche bun from them, and it was a good day. first, the only drawback about this place is that it is kind of pircey, so minus a star there, but for the kind of baked goods you get, this bakery really is tops. this place makes the best croissants, hands-down. they're light, airy, flaky, and buttery. i've had the almond and the chocolate ones, and they're absolutely divine. these guys can bake. unlike other bakeries where the breads come out really thick and heavy, all the breads here are really flaky and airy, just the way bread should be. i've also had their whole wheat loaves and other assorted baked goods. it's true, you can get a bigger loaf for your buck from panorama or other bakeries, but there's something about the brioche's bread that just makes it so much better. now, onto the brioche. i've had brioches before, and they weren't good. the brioche bakery's brioche is just like their other baked goods, light and airy, and yet decadent at the same time. it's not too sweet or salty. it's the perfect bread. these guys can bake. check them out when you've got the chance.
author: Danny C.

description: So, i finally decided to try this place on my way to work today and I have to put it down in words...the Brioche was OUTSTANDING. Light, fluffy, moist with the buttery flavor you want without feeling like you ate a stick. This will be a dangerous little place but well worth it!
author: Gigi H.
